Assignment of already defined cost centers to materials.



Field Descriptions

Text:

Name of the material

Text:

Cost object

Cost Unit:

A cost object is an object to which costs are allocated in business accounting. Usually, this is understood to be a good or service. However, other objects can also be selected as cost objects in business cost accounting, such as a process (activity-based costing), a project (project costing) or a customer (customer profitability accounting).

Text:

Cost center

Cost Center:

The cost center is a spatially or organizationally delimited place of an organization where costs are incurred. Cost centers correspond, for example, to individual machines or other delimited materials.

Text:

Cost type

Cost Element:

The cost element categorizes costs incurred in cost accounting according to their own nature. Here, each cost element corresponds to an assigned task.

Text:

Activity type

Service Type:

The activity type in cost accounting is a reference value that indicates the qualitative technical description of the production activity. Here, it can be classified between productive (=value-adding) and non-productive types.




Material list


List of all materials in the company sorted by article number, which meet the filter criteria previously set in the selection mask.



Field Descriptions

Del.:

This field indicates whether the related field for this profile may be deleted.

Stat.:

Status of a stock item, i.e. it is warned in traffic light colors if there are too few or too many materials in the stock.

Int. Item Number:

Unique internal article number of a material.

Ext. Item Number:

External article number of a material, which does not necessarily have to be unique, since this number was usually assigned by an external company.

Material Name:

Name or description of a material.

Usage Category:

Usage type of a material, that is, for which purposes this material is used.

Instant materials are materials that are assigned to tasks once, whereby the corresponding costs and/or revenues are transferred directly to the project budget, e.g. computers, printers, etc.

Consumable materials are materials that can be consumed by a person on a unit basis (pieces, meters, etc.) on a daily basis, e.g. cables, sockets, etc.

Time materials are materials that can be consumed by a person on an hourly basis and to the day, analogous to time recording, e.g. company cars, rented rooms, etc.

Material Type:

Type of a material, that is, to which material group it belongs. The material types can be defined as lookup values themselves.

Task:

Task for which an immediate material was purchased. (This field is hidden for consumable or time materials).

Amount:

How much of a material was purchased or consumed.

Unit:

Unit of the material, e.g. piece, kg, m, etc. The units can be defined as lookup values themselves. For time materials, the unit is always "hrs".

Purchase/start date:

The purchase date of an immediate material, or the effective start date of a consumable or time material.

Invoice/end date:

The invoice date of an immediate material, or the effective end date of a consumable or time material.

Stock:

Indicates whether the consumable is a stock item (= ) or not (= ) .

Stock Loc.:

Location where a stock consumable is stored.

Text:

Cost object

Stock Min.:

Number of minimum available consumables in the warehouse, i.e. this is how many materials should always be in stock in the warehouse.
This value is mainly used to check the stock in order to see immediately what should be reordered.

Stock Max.:

Maximum number of consumables available in the warehouse, i.e. the maximum number of materials that can or should be in stock in the warehouse.
This value is mainly used as a control upper limit for reordering materials.

Text:

Cost center

Stock Ent.:

Total number of receipts of consumables into the warehouse, that is, the total number of materials by which the warehouse stock was increased.

Text:

Cost type

Stock Rem.:

The total number of issues of consumables from the warehouse, that is, the total number of materials by which the warehouse stock was reduced.

Text:

Activity type

Stock Act.:

Number of total consumables currently available in the warehouse. This value corresponds to the difference between the total inflow (= material increase) minus the total outflow (= material reduction).

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Stock Used:

Total number of consumables already consumed from the warehouse, i.e. materials withdrawn from the warehouse. This value is determined from the total number of day-specific entries recorded for material consumption.

Planned-Actual-Comp.:

Calculation formula:

Target/Actual comparison= ACT (= sum of all efforts made so far)
Target (= sum of planned efforts)


The target/actual comparison is the simplest method to determine the degree of progress of a project. A prerequisite for this is good effort planning.

The percentage of completion can be adjusted at any time by changing the effort planning.
For an effective determination of the POC, all methods must be considered and evaluated together!

Plnd.Cost/Unit:

Planned costs of an immediate material per unit, that is, these costs are acquisition costs of an ordered but not yet paid immediate material.

(For consumables or time materials, this value is always 0.00)

Act. Cost/Unit:

Purchase price (EK) per unit, which have an impact on the internal budget (= costs of the company).

Sale Price/Unit:

Sales price (VK) per unit, which has an impact on the external budget (= revenue of the company, which can be settled with a client).

Plnd. Cost/Tot.:

Planned total costs of an immediate material of all units, that is, these costs are acquisition costs of all ordered but not yet paid immediate materials.

Formula:
Planned total cost = Planned cost per unit * Quantity

(For consumable or time materials, this value is always 0.00)

Purch Cost/Tot.:

Total purchase prices (EKs) of all units, which have an impact on the internal budget (= costs of the company).

Formula:
Total purchase price = purchase price per unit * quantity

Sale Price/Tot.:

Total sales prices (VKs) of all units, which have an impact on the external budget (= revenue of the company, which can be settled with a client).

Formula:
Total sales price = sales price per unit * quantity

U-Margin:

Consumption margin for a project, i.e. the difference between ext. consumed budget and int. consumed budget.

Invoice No:

The placeholder for the invoice number is an admin setting value.

MT (Open):

This value indicates the externally still open, i.e. not settled (is) net costs for immediate materials.

MT (Invo.):

This value indicates the already externally billed (is) net cost for immediate materials.

I-Margin:

Invoice margin for a project, i.e. the difference between ext. settled budget and int. consumed budget.
If no invoice writing is used, this value is always negative, if int. budget was consumed.

Act.:

Click on this icon to execute the displayed action, i.e. open material to change or delete.

Creation > Travel Allowances > Allowances: km/Non-monetary Renumeration

Creation or modification of fixed fees per km and non-monetary renumerations


Settings for travel expense per diems, such as mileage allowance or meals.

The automatic calculations of the travel expense program are based on the travel expense flat rates stored here.

In this program function you can store the currently valid statutory mileage allowances for the various vehicle types and passengers, as well as per diems and reductions for meals for domestic and international trips.

This program function is a standard administrator program and can only be customized by individuals with appropriate administrator privileges.

NOTE:
Make sure to always store the currently valid statutory per diems, otherwise trips can no longer be accounted for correctly for tax purposes! These can be found in the official country list of the Federal Ministry of Finance.




Settings


Here, various settings can be changed according to personal preferences, e.g. the "Date format", the "Decimal separator", the "Number of decimal places", the "Number of list entries", the "Sort order of projects", etc.

Grayed settings have not yet been adjusted, i.e. these contain the specified original default values of your client.

User settings that have already been adjusted can be reset to the original default value by checking the "Delete" checkbox in front of the corresponding setting value.

A click on the "question mark" at the end of the line opens a separate help window for the corresponding setting value with an exact description of the change options.



Field Descriptions

Del.:

This field indicates whether the related field for this profile may be deleted.

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Setting:

Short description of the setting. Extracted settings have not been changed yet, i.e. these still have the original default value.

Setting Value:

Set value of the setting. This value can be changed according to personal preferences.

Icon:

Specifies which icon is used with this entry.


Multi Function

Clicking this button saves the entered data and continues the program execution.

Creation > Travel Allowances > Allowances: Overnight Stay

Creation of meal and accommodation allowances at home and abroad


In this program function you can store the currently valid statutory per diems for additional expenses for meals and overnight expenses for domestic and international trips. For each country, you can specify per diems for a length of stay of less than 14 hours but at least 8 hours, less than 24 hours but at least 14 hours, and for 24 hours (in accordance with German tax law until 12/31/2013). Alternatively, you can declare per diems for each country for the day of arrival and departure as well as for 24 hours if the duration of stay is less than 24 hours but at least 8 hours (in accordance with German tax law as of 01.01.2014). The corresponding overnight flat rate can also be entered here.

With the help of the validity period you can determine the validity period of the respective per diems.

With the integrated search function, desired per diems can be found quickly and adjusted if necessary.

NOTE:
Make sure to always store the currently valid statutory per diems, otherwise trips can no longer be accounted for correctly for tax purposes!
This program function is a standard administrator program and can only be adapted by persons with corresponding administrator rights.




Selection


In this mask, you can store the currently valid statutory per diems for additional subsistence expenses and accommodation costs for domestic and international trips. For each country, you can enter per diems for a length of stay of less than 14 but at least 8 hours, less than 24 but at least 14 hours, and for 24 hours. The corresponding accommodations per diem can also be entered here.

With the help of the validity period, you can determine the validity period of the relevant per diems.

Here you can select which travel expense per diems you want to display and, if necessary, adjust or create. By clicking on the button Display you will see a list of all travel expense per diems currently in the system for domestic and international trips with the corresponding trip duration as well as accommodations per diems and their validity.

NOTE:
Always make sure to store the currently valid statutory per diems, otherwise trips can no longer be accounted correctly for tax purposes!



Field Descriptions

A-Group:

Tax groups of the lump sums for additional subsistence expenses and accommodation costs.

Search from:

In this search field you can define the validity start of the time frame of the search.

Search up to:

In this search field you can set the validity end of the time frame of the search.

Search Txt:

With the help of the search function, you can quickly and specifically display the desired per diems, if necessary also with restriction of the search to a specific period.


Display

By clicking on this button, the list is generated and displayed. Depending on the defined selection criteria, the list is filtered accordingly.




Administration


In this screen, you can store, adjust, and remove the currently valid statutory per diems for additional subsistence expenses and accommodations costs for domestic and international trips.

For each country, you can specify per diems for a length of stay of less than 14 but at least 8 hours, less than 24 but at least 14 hours, and for 24 hours. The corresponding accommodation per diem can also be entered here.

The current flat rates can be found in the official country list of the Federal Ministry of Finance.

With the help of the validity period, you can determine the validity period of the relevant per diems.

NOTE:
Always make sure to deposit the currently valid legal per diems, otherwise trips can no longer be accounted for correctly for tax purposes!



Field Descriptions

Del.:

Here you can set a checkmark if the relevant country per diem is to be deleted.

Land / Place:

Enter here the country or the place for which the respective additional expenses for meals and overnight expenses per diems are to apply.

Arr./Dep.:

Here you can store the per diem for the arrival or departure day of trips.
Always make sure to deposit the currently valid legal per diems, otherwise trips can no longer be correctly accounted for tax purposes!

over 8 h:

Here, the per diem meal allowance can be deposited for trips of at least 8 hours but less than 24 hours. (For trips before 01.01.2014 less than 14 hours).
Make sure to always deposit the currently valid statutory per diems, otherwise trips can no longer be accounted for correctly for tax purposes!

over 14 h:

Here you can deposit the per diem for meals for trips with a duration of at least 14 but less than 24 hours.
Always make sure to deposit the currently valid legal per diems, otherwise trips can no longer be accounted for correctly for tax purposes!

for 24 h:

Here the per diem for meals per day for trips with a travel duration of exactly 24 hours can be deposited.
Always make sure to deposit the currently valid legal per diems, otherwise trips can no longer be correctly accounted for tax purposes!

Accom.:

Here you can enter the flat rate for accommodation costs per night.

Overnight stay allowances can only be granted if the traveller is an employee. The employer can reimburse his employee for overnight expenses tax-free: In the amount of the expenses proven by receipt or, without proof, in the amount of the flat-rate amount, which varies from country to country, insofar as the employee did not receive the accommodation free of charge or at a reduced price from the employer or from a third party due to his employment relationship.

The tax-free payment of the lump sum is also not permitted in the case of overnight accommodation in a vehicle. In the case of use of a sleeping car or a ship's cabin, the lump sums may only be paid tax-free if the overnight stay has begun or ended in another accommodation.

For such days, the overnight allowances shall be deactivated.

Since 2008, entrepreneurs can no longer claim any lump sums for overnight stays at all. Costs for overnight stays can now only be claimed by entrepreneurs as business expenses in the amount actually incurred, which must be proven by receipt.
Always make sure to deposit the currently valid statutory flat rates, otherwise trips can no longer be correctly accounted for tax purposes!

Valid from:

Here you can store the date from which the specified lump sums are valid. Pay attention to legal changes and adjust the validity period accordingly.

Valid to:

Here you can store until when the specified lump sums are valid. Pay attention to legal changes and adjust the validity period accordingly.

Created by:

This field contains the ID of the user who entered the document into the system.


Del.

Button to save data.

Planning > Projects > Search

Search and list specific projects, subprojects or tasks


Extensive selection and filter criteria such as search text, time period, project name, PCA code, project owner, etc. can be used to search for specific projects. All filter criteria can be combined with each other to sift the number of hits until the desired result is displayed.




Project search


Project search

Search for a specific project.

The criteria that can be entered are:
- "Project name"
- "project type= type of project"
- "planned start date"
- "planned end date".
If no criterion is entered, then all existing projects are listed.



Field Descriptions

Search Text:

This field is used to enter the string to search for.

Search from:

In this search field you can define the validity start of the time frame of the search.

To:

In this search field you can set the validity end of the time frame of the search.

Project Type:

In this field the project type is displayed or can be chosen from a selection list, i.e. this field indicates which project it is, whether "mother project", "sub-project" or "task".

Name of Project:

Display of the project name or the name of the activity (project, subproject, task).

1st Project L.:

In this field the manager of a project is displayed or must be selected from a selection list. The project manager is defined once in the master project, and is then preselected as a PROPOSAL in all underlying projects.

Green displayed persons in the selection field are project leaders, which are already assigned to at least one project in this role.

Project managers are created using the role mask with role "Project Manager".

PCA Code:

PCA is short for Pproject Codification Algorithm, which is a unique identifier to each project.

Customer:

Here you can select the client of the activity (project, subproject or task).

ID:

Primary key of the entry.


Search

Clicking on this button starts the search.




Overview of all found projects


Overview of all found projects

Here you get an overview of all found projects of the previous search.

The adjacent button for each project found takes you to the project input mask for this project.



Field Descriptions

No.:

This is the directory number for a project.

The directory number cannot be changed for parent projects.

The directory number is automatically adjusted when deleting or moving.

By manually changing the directory number, you can move projects within a hierarchy.

Project Name:

Display of the project name or the name of the activity (project, subproject, task).

ID:

Primary key of the entry.

Project Type:

In this field the project type is displayed or can be chosen from a selection list, i.e. this field indicates which project it is, whether "mother project", "sub-project" or "task".

Pln. Start:

The target start date of the project is displayed or specified here, i.e. from when the project is to be started according to planning.

Pln. End:

The target end date of the respective reference object, e.g. project, time data, trip data, etc. is displayed or specified here, i.e. by when the object should be completed according to planning.

1st Project L.:

In this field the manager of a project is displayed or must be selected from a selection list. The project manager is defined once in the master project, and is then preselected as a PROPOSAL in all underlying projects.

Green displayed persons in the selection field are project leaders, which are already assigned to at least one project in this role.

Project managers are created using the role mask with role "Project Manager".

Customer:

Here you can select the client of the activity (project, subproject or task).

PCA Code:

PCA is short for Pproject Codification Algorithm, which is a unique identifier to each project.

Link:

This field is optional. If a link is entered, the automatic user rights query is bypassed and the Trans_ID field is cleared.

Planning > Projects > Matrix: Graphically as Gantt

Planning an existing project graphically by means of Gantt charts


Tasks (projects, sub-projects + tasks) including any existing sub-tasks can be changed or deleted quickly and easily. It is also possible to create several new projects at the same time.

The fields to be edited can be defined and selected by the user. The deadline shift can optionally also be carried out graphically.


NOTE:
It should be noted that the number of selected rows and columns can affect the amount of data and thus the response times. The maximum number of rows to be displayed can be set by the administrator (default = 100).




Project selection


Selection of the project to be edited or extended.



Field Descriptions

Main Project:

Selection of the parent project or subproject, which is to be processed graphically.


Select

Clicking on this button will forward the selected data.




Matrix/Gantt


The matrix is divided into four horizontal sections:


Title line:

The title line contains the title of the program function. On the right side is the save button for saving the changes made, as well as the standard maximization icon for enlarging the main window.


Toolbar:

The toolbar contains various icons for making changes, setting the display area, opening resource planning, and navigation aids. On the right side is an icon to set the columns to display for the project details area (see below).


Toolbar icons:
Undo: Undo last change [Ctrl]+[Z] (A maximum of the last 25 changes can be undone.)
Redo: Redo last undo [Ctrl]+[Shift]+[Z]
Set the zoom factor for the Gantt resolution (= number of days displayed / width per day). The zoom factor can be set from 1x (= Many days in the display area, but each day very narrow) to 64x (= Few days in the display area, but each day very large).
Customize Gantt display area with best width and zoom factor based on project period.
Resource planning area to be enlargedö&extent;or reduced.
Jump in Gantt to the beginning of the selected task.
Expand or collapse all displayed subprojects.
Hide all completed level 1 subprojects or show all hidden subprojects.
Gantt center on today's date. (If this exists in the time range.).
Jump the Gantt to the end of the selected operation.
Specify the columns to be displayed in the project details area. In the selection field next to it, already defined column constellations can be selected.

Data:

The data area is again divided into three vertical sections, which can be selected by clicking on the icons < to zoom out or > can be resized.


Project structure
If specified in the settings, a prefix for the complete project can be specified, changed or deleted in the title bar.
In the data area, the structure of the project tree is displayed line by line, arranged according to project level.
A subordinate hierarchy can be expanded by clicking on the icon or expanded again by clicking on the icon.
A level 1 subproject can be expanded by clicking on the or by clicking on the icon .
By double-clicking on the last underlined number of a project number, a task or a complete hierarchy can be renumbered.
By double-clicking on a project name, or by pressing [F2] on a highlighted project, a project name can be renamed.
By left-clicking on a project name, this project will be marked and the following action icons will be shown:

Action icons:
Add new subproject.
Add new task.
#### Bild [ic_type.png] fehlt! ### Convert task type, i.e. subproject to task and vice versa.
Move task one level to the left (= one level higher in the structure).
Move one level to the right (= one level lower in the structure).
Copy selected operation incl. all subordinate operations behind this operation.
Copy selected operation incl. all subordinate operations. of all subordinate processes move behind this process.
Delete process including all subordinate processes.

Project Detail
Displays a wide variety of project attributes as a table. Project attributes are displayed as columns and are for example status, priority, effort, time period, persons responsible for the project, budget fields, descriptions or resource planning. Depending on the project type, certain contents can be changed.

The columns to be displayed can be defined in the toolbar by clicking on the icon , as well as by selecting already defined column constellations.

Project Attributes Columns:
StatusSelect box: Scheduled, Active, Inactive, or Completed
PrioritätSelect box: low, medium, high, or immediate
Gepl. EffortInput field: Planned target effort in hours, which can be defined for tasks and is cumulated to higher-level projects.
Tats. EffortOnly display field: Actual effort in hours. Values are determined from the time recorded for tasks and are cumulated to higher-level projects.
Max. EffortInput field: Maximum actual effort in hours, which can be defined for tasks and is cumulated up to higher-level projects. This value defines the upper limit of billable actual hours, i.e. up to this value times may be recorded.
Planned periodDisplay field only: Planned target period. These values are determined from start and end times of the respective operation in the Gantt.
Actual periodDisplay field only: Actual period. These values are determined from start and end times from completed time recording for tasks and are cumulated to higher-level projects.
DeadlineInput field: Planned final date by which a task should be completed. If a task is moved beyond the deadline, the deadline will be adjusted automatically.
Project managerSelection field: Main responsible and mostly administrative person on main project level. Supervisor and contact person of project managers from subordinate subprojects/tasks. The project manager can only be set at project level and inherits automatically downwards.
Project managerSelect field: main responsible and mostly administrative person at subproject/task level. The project manager is mostly responsible for resource planning, managing and controlling of his assigned subprojects/tasks.
Deputy project managerSelection field: The deputy project manager has in principle the same area of responsibility as the project manager. However, he usually only appears when the project manager is out of the house.
Contact person clientSelection field: Defines the contact person or the client of a project, i.e. who has assigned the project. This value is especially important for invoicing, since invoices for this task can only be issued to the person specified here.
Invoicing typeSelect field: Fixed price, Hourly basis or Not billable. For fixed price tasks, up to 100% of the planned budget can be billed from active tasks on a percentage basis (Time tracking is not required). For hourly based tasks, the amount to be billed is determined by the time or material entry. For non-billable tasks, only travel costs can be accounted for and not hourly or material costs.
Budget TypeSelect field: Informative field to distinguish budgets. The values listed here come from the self-definable lookup values.
Int. PB FrameInput field: the "Internal person budget frame" can only be entered for projects. It sets the estimated upper limit of all expenses for persons in all subordinate tasks.
Int. planned PBInput field: The "Internal planned person budget" can only be entered for tasks. It specifies the estimated upper limit of the incurred expenses for persons.
Int. planned PBDisplay field only: The "Internally planned person budget" shows the incurred expenses for persons. This value is determined from the time recording of each employee (= hours * purchase price).
Ext. PB FrameInput field: The "External person budget frame" can only be entered for projects. It sets the estimated upper limit of all summed up revenues of persons in all subordinated tasks.
Ext. planned PBInput field: The "External planned person budget" can only be entered for tasks. It sets the estimated upper limit of the summed up revenues of persons.
Ext. planned PBDisplay field only: The "Externally planned person budget" shows the summed up revenues of persons. This value is determined from each employee's time tracking (= hours * sales price).
Ext. abger. PBDisplay field only: The "Externally billed person budget" shows the summed billed revenue of persons. This value is determined from the accounting of fixed price person revenues, hourly base person revenues and travel expenses.
Int. MB FrameInput field: The "Internal Material Budget Frame" can only be entered for projects. It specifies the estimated upper limit of all incurred expenses for material in all subordinate tasks.
Int. planned MBInput field: The "Internally planned material budget" can only be entered for tasks. It sets the estimated upper limit of the incurred expenses for material.
Int. planned MBDisplay field only: The "Internally consumed material budget" shows the incurred expenses for material. This value is determined from the material allocation.
Ext. MB frameInput field: The "External material budget frame" can only be entered for projects. It sets the estimated upper limit of all summed up receipts of sold materials in all subordinated tasks.
Ext. planned MBInput field: The "External planned material budget" can only be entered for tasks. It sets the estimated upper limit of the summed revenues of sold materials.
Ext. consumed MBDisplay field only: The "Externally consumed material budget" shows the summed revenues of sold materials. This value is determined from the material allocation.
Ext. abger. MBDisplay field only: The "Externally billed material budget" displays the totaled billed revenue of sold materials. This value is determined from the billing of fixed price material revenue, hourly base material revenue and individual material revenue.
Project CategoryDisplay Field: Informative field to distinguish and group projects. The values listed here come from the user-definable lookup values.
FähigkeitengruppeSelection field: Specifies the most needed skill for a successful completion of this project - this value serves e.g. as a filter criterion when assigning resources or for reports. The values listed here come from the self-definable lookup values.
Progress determination m.Select field: defines how the progress of this project should be determined. Possible values: comparison target/actual effort (= default), completion percentage, method 0/100, method 0/50/100, remaining effort in hours + remaining effort percentage.
Reference numberInput field: Informative field to distinguish projects.
DescriptionInput field: Detailed text to describe the project.
NoteInput field: Text for project-specific features.
Internal noteInput field: Text für company-internal project-specific features.
Assigned personSelect field: Specifies the resource assignment, i.e. who should process this task. For tasks, only a direct 1:1 assignment is possible, i.e. one person is responsible for one task. If more than one person should work on this task, the extended resource planning area or the independent resource planning program functionality must be used.
Purchase priceInput field: Sets the purchase price (= EK) for the assigned person. The EC is the basis for the determination of the internal person budget, i.e. how much costs the employee of the company per hour of work on this task.
Sales priceInput field: Sets the sales price (= VK) for the assigned person. The VK is the basis für the determination of the external person budget (= billable amount), i.e. how much revenue the employee brings to the company per hour of work on this task.

Gantt
The Gantt area consists of a table-like structure with date fields as columns and projects as rows. The boundaries of the parent project are represented by dashed vertical lines. The &u>
|<Scroll to the top of the time range.
>|Scroll to the end of the time range.
+ ++Minimally or maximally increase the time range, i.e. add some or more additional date columns either at the beginning or at the end. The icons will be displayed if scrolled to the time range start or end.

At the lower left edge there is a fade-in navigationüoverview to quickly scroll to the desired time range. The navigation overview can be expanded and collapsed by clicking on the arrow icon.

Task:

A task consists of a graphical bar, as well as a start and end node. Operations are graphically distinguished as follows:

Project/Subproject (= collective task)Dient for grouping tasks.
Task (= work package)Dient for recording work steps. Only to tasks can effort be planned, resources assigned and time records, etc. durchgeführt be carried out.

An operation can have different statuses, which are also represented graphically in a task:

planned (= light grey + rounded)The task is still in the planning phase, i.e. the effort and budget estimation has not yet been completed. No actual data can be collected yet.
active (= dark grey + rounded)The task is active, i.e. the planning phase is completed and the task can be worked on. Time, material and travel costs can be recorded.
inactive (= light grey + angular)The task is inactive, d.i.e. the planning phase has been completed, but no time, material or travel costs should be able to be recorded for it.
completed (= black + square)The task is completed, i.e. the task goal has been achieved and no additional time, material or travel costs should be able to be recorded.

Assigned resources of a task are displayed as an attached text box (= small flag) to the right of the task. If there is more than one assigned resource, the number is displayed in bold.
A subordinate hierarchy of a project/subproject can be expanded by clicking on the icon or expanded again by clicking on the icon.
A task can be renamed by double-clicking on a task name in the bar or by pressing [F2] on a selected task.
By clicking with the left mouse button on a task bar, this task will be marked, and the following action icons will be shown:

Action icons:
Copy highlighted operation including all subordinate operations graphically.
Move selected process including all subordinate processes graphically.
Graphically move selected operation including all subordinate operations vertically.
Expand or shrink resource planning area.
Procedure incl. By clicking and holding the left mouse button on a process bar, this process can be shifted in time. Please note that a subproject or a task cannot be moved beyond the time frame of the parent project.
By clicking and holding the left mouse button on a start or end node, this task can be extended or shortened. Note here that a parent project cannot be made shorter than its child predecessors.

Milestone:

There are two different types of milestones:

DynamicA dynamic milestone is connected to the start or end node of a task, a time shift of x days is possible. A dynamic milestone automatically moves with the assigned task.
FixedA fixed milestone is connected to the task, but it is independent of time. A fixed milestone always remains fixed at its position and does not move with the assigned task.

By double-clicking on a milestone name, or by pressing [F2] on a selected milestone, it can be renamed.
By clicking and holding down the left mouse button on a milestone, it can be moved in time.

Dependencies:

Dependencies are represented by arrows from a node of one task to a node of another task. There are four different types of dependencies:

(EA) end-to-end
(EE) end-to-end
(AA) start-to-start
(AE) start-to-end

A dependency can be created graphically by clicking and holding down the left mouse button on a chaining symbol and then dragging the dependency arrow to the desired start or end node of the target operation. Invalid dependency relationships are shown as "red" arrows .

Resource Planning:

The resource planning section is again divided into two vertical sections.


Resource Planning
Displays assigned and selected resources, sorted in descending order by their name.
A resource can be assigned to a task by checking the checkbox in front of it, or removed by unchecking it. A resource assigned to the task is displayed green.
A resource can be removed from a task by clicking on the delete icon to the right of the resource name and simultaneously removed from the view. The resource will be written back to the resource pool.
Clicking on the resource pool icon at the end of the resource listing will open the resource pool.

Resource Pool:
NameName, first name (username) and [employee type] of the resource. By clicking on the add icon at the beginning of the line, the corresponding resource is added to the resource list. The resource is not assigned to the task.
Available hours.Available hours of the corresponding resource in the selected period. The hours are calculated from the target hours of the corresponding resource in the selected period minus already assigned active planned hours of tasks, which are not displayed in the Gantt, i.e. which do not belong to the current parent project.
Standard EKPurchase price (= EK), which was stored for the corresponding resource. Resource was deposited.
Standard VKSales price (= VK), which was deposited für the entspr. resource.
FähigkeitenFähigkeitsgruppen und Fähigkeiten, welche für die entspr. Ressource hinterlegt wurden. A matching skill with the skill stored in the task is highlighted in red.

The individual resource attributes are displayed as columns. Depending on the assignment, certain content (percentage, purchase price, or sales price) can be changed.

Resource attribute columns:
PercentageInput field if more than one resource is assigned, otherwise Only display field: Values can be entered from 1.00% to 99.00%. For a single assigned resource the value always corresponds to 100.00%, for an unassigned resource 0.00%.
Purchase priceInput field, if the resource is assigned, otherwise Only display field: Purchase price (= EK), which should be used for the corresponding resource specifically for this task. This value is preset with the default price of the corresponding resource.
Sales priceInput field, if the resource is assigned, otherwise Only display field: Sales price (= VK), which should be used for the corresponding resource specifically for this task. This value is preset with the default sales price of the corresponding resource.
Entry dateDisplay field only: Date when the corresponding resource joined the company (or when the resource joined the company). Resource has joined (or will join) the company.
Exit dateDisplay field only: Date when the corresponding resource has left (or will leave) the company. Open, if the date has not been set yet.
Working daysOnly display field: Number of working days per week, as well as the corresponding weekday count.
Working hours/weekOnly display field: Number of target working hours per week (according to the employment contract).
Working hours./dayDisplay field only: number of target working hours per week (according to the employment contract) divided by the number of working days per week.

Resource utilization
The resource utilization area consists of a table-like structure according to the Gantt area with date fields as columns and individual daily workloads per resource as rows. An exact composition of the utilization per day is displayed as a tooltip when you move the mouse over a daily utilization.

Daily workloads:
 
0.00% utilization = completely available
 
0.01% to 100.00% utilization = OK
 
100.01% to 150.00% utilization = warning, utilization should be checked
 
> 150.00% utilization = ¨overload
U
Vacation
S
Training
G
Slip Day
K
Sick
A
Absent


context menü + key commands:

Right-click on the bar of a task (= project, subproject or task), a milestone or a dependency, the commands possible at this point are displayed in a context menu. These commands can be clicked with the mouse or executed via key commands (see below).


To control and edit the project plan, keys or key combinations are defined that allow you to work quickly.



Control key commands:

F1
Hide or show this help text
Switch to the previous object of the selected object type (project, milestone or dependency)
Switch to the next object of the selected object type (project, milestone or dependency)
Move selected operation one layer to the left
Move selected operation one layer to the right
+
Expand selected project
-
Close selected project


Process key commands:

F2
Rename selected operation
P
roject
Insert new subproject below selected task


Field Descriptions

Chart:

If this checkbox is ticked, the data displayed in the report is also shown in a meaningful diagram.

Planning > Projects > Detail: Text Form with Diagrams

Plan an existing project in text form


In the core of fx-project tasks (projects, sub-projects and tasks) can be managed, i.e. recorded, modified, deleted or displayed.

The data areas thereby extend into six data blocks, namely:

  • Data block (project number, name, status, main, additional and executing persons, description etc.).)
  • Date block (Start date, End date, Deadline, Target effort etc.)
  • Finance block (Budget frame, Settlement type, Internal and External budget fields etc.)
  • Progress block (Determination method + reporting dates)
  • Cost master data block (Cost objects, cost centers + cost elements)
  • Info block (Reference number, notes, etc.)




Selecting and opening a project


Open project

Select a project from the existing tasks (project, subproject, task). Here you can select from the projects authorized to you.

By pressing the button Display Project the selected project is taken over in the following mask.



Field Descriptions

Internal number of a project that is automatically assigned when it is created.:

This field contains the internal number of a project. It is automatically assigned when projects are created and serves as the unique identification number (ID) of the project.


Display

Graphically display all projects that match the above selection criteria.




Selecting the project type


Here you can determine the type of project (e.g. subproject) and the position at which it should be placed.

Selection of the desired project type and the position of your project to be edited.

In the new project mode, this is the only mask you will see at first. Select here the project type of the new project and the desired parent, i.e. to which project the new project should be subordinated.

Finally click on Accept.
In change mode, this mask is initially only grayed out.
If you want to change the project type or position of a project, click on Reset Values to activate the mask.
Carry out the desired changes, click on Accept, make further changes to the data of the project, if desired, and finally click on OK.

There are certain restrictions regarding project type and position, for example, a project of type "Project" cannot have a parent. If you would violate such a restriction, you will be informed by an error message.



Field Descriptions

Project Type:

In this field the project type is displayed or can be chosen from a selection list, i.e. this field indicates which project it is, whether "mother project", "sub-project" or "task".

Allocated to:

This field contains the "parent unit".
For projects, this would be the parent project [(sub)project].

For documents this would be the unit you belong to (e.g. project, appointment, note etc.).


Accept

Clicking this button saves the entered data and continues the program execution.

Back

Jump back to the previous mask/page.




Data block for the activity (project, subproject, task)


Information on current projects

You will see various fields that contain general information about your project, such as project name, project manager, customer, etc.

Furthermore, a little further down, three history fields are displayed that reflect the state of your project.

Depending on how the individual bars are colored, so is the state of the project:

- green = within planning,

- yellow = slightly exceeded [0%-10%],

- red = serious exceedance [+10%].

The filling level indicates how many of the individual measured values have already been required.

Example: A half-filled red bar means that 50% of the time, effort, or budget has been used so far, but the project itself is not yet 50% complete (but at most 40%, since the bar is colored red). If the bar were yellow, the degree of completion would be between 41% and 50%, if it were green, the degree of completion would be greater than 50%.
=> The fill level indicates the percentage used value of the field, the color signals how this value relates to the POC.

If you move the mouse over a bar, a window is displayed in which you can see the graphically visualized information again in plain text.

The project manager and the deputy are given access to the project, as are any employee resources that may be assigned later (see Resource Planning).

If you enter a skill here, this will later be taken into account in resource planning, i.e. only those employees will be proposed who have exactly this skill.

If the status of a (sub)project is changed, this change also affects all subordinate projects.



Field Descriptions

No.:

This is the directory number for a project.

The directory number cannot be changed for parent projects.

The directory number is automatically adjusted when deleting or moving.

By manually changing the directory number, you can move projects within a hierarchy.

Project Number:

Directory number for a project

Name of Project:

In the project name, the name or designation of the task (project, subproject, task) is specified.

Allocated to Object:

This field contains the "parent unit".
For projects, this would be the parent project [(sub)project].

For documents this would be the unit you belong to (e.g. project, appointment, note etc.).

Dependent upon Proj.:

If one project is dependent on another, then the dependent project can only be started after the predecessor has been completed.

If there are delays in the predecessor, this means that the successor (dependent project) is also delayed, but this is not automatically managed by the program, but must be explicitly executed by the user!

Each project can be set from each, already created project, in dependence.

PCA Code:

PCA is short for Pproject Codification Algorithm, which is a unique identifier to each project.

Milestone Name:

Specifies the name of a milestone - usually [milestone] in conjunction with an integer (e.g. milestone 2, or milestone 3.1.2).

Project Type:

In this field the project type is displayed or can be chosen from a selection list, i.e. this field indicates which project it is, whether "mother project", "sub-project" or "task".

Status:

This field shows how far a project has already progressed. In input mode, you can assign an attribute from a selection list to a project here, which reflects whether or how far a project is already advanced.

The status can also be used to decide whether project data should be included in a report or not.

Priority:

Indicates the urgency of the (sub)project.
The higher the priority of a project, the higher it is displayed in the control panel of an employee.

Archived:

If this archiving flag is set, projects marked as archived are hidden in the project menu and in the selection fields.

Release:

The release indicates whether the record has been released for settlement.

Contact Person Cust.:

Selection of the contact person from the client

Project Manager:

The project manager of the task (project, subproject or task) is selected here.

1st Project Leader:

The project manager of the activity (project, subproject or task) is selected here.

2nd Project Leader:

The deputy project manager of the task (project, subproject or task) is selected here.

Last Edited by:

Indicates which user last edited a record.

Budget Approval:

Indicates who is allowed to approve planned budgets. As a rule, these are the management as well as persons assigned to the project who have the employee role [budget approval].
If it is specified in the administrator settings for the client that budgets are approved automatically, this is where: [automatic]

Persons:

Here you can select which employees should be included in the cost report.

Person:

This selection field is used to select the person whose data is to be edited or displayed depending on the action.

PP:

This is the monetary value, the amount of which shows the financial expenditure for the company per hour of use of a worker or a material (counterpart to VK=sales price).

SP:

This is the monetary value, the amount of which shows the financial return for the company per day of use of a worker or a material (counterpart to EK=purchase price).

Funded Project:

Indicates whether this project is a grant project.

Fund. Pr. Attributes:

Parameters of the funding project properties.

Skill Group:

Here the required skill can be specified, which will be necessary to successfully work on the project.

If an entry is selected here, the resource planning will list those employees who have the necessary skill.

Project Categories:

Define filter categories for projects or select them in a selection field.

Project Location:

Location where the project will be carried out. For construction projects, this can also be the construction site.

Description:

Explanatory descriptions, details, comments or similar.




Appointment block contains dates and effort specifications


The appointment block contains appointments and dates.

The display type of this mask depends on the project type of the project you have just opened.

The field Actual Effort is only editable for tasks, for (partial) projects it is always formatted as a "read-only field". The reason for this is that the effort target for (sub)projects is equal to the cumulative effort target of all subtasks.

Another special feature is that all actual fields are filled via the time recording, i.e. the Actual Effort results from all time account entries of the employees for this project.

The Actual Starting Date is the same as the date of the earliest time account entry for this project. The filling of the Actual End Date field is handled analogously.



Field Descriptions

Planned Start Date:

The target start date of the project is displayed or specified here, i.e. from when the project is to be started according to planning.

Start Date Parent:

Displays the planned start date of the predecessor, i.e. the parent project.

This display only appears in create and change mode and is intended as an aid, as a note is reported as soon as a project is created under a project that would lie outside the period of the parent project.

If defined in the global client settings, the system tries to adjust the time period of the parent projects automatically, if no dependencies are violated.

Planned Effort:

The target effort corresponds to the planned time effort in hours, man-days or man-years, etc. The estimated effort is entered when defining tasks. For projects/sub-projects, this value corresponds to the sum of all subordinate tasks.

Alias field for time unit:

Alias field for time unit, which should guarantee that the different fields linked to the time unit (effort_set, effort_actual, max. time effort, actual_delay, set_delay) can be handled individually.
(ZE=Unit of Time)
A day is defined as 8 hours
A month is defined as 30 days
A year is defined as 12 months

Planned End Date:

The target end date of the respective reference object, e.g. project, time data, trip data, etc. is displayed or specified here, i.e. by when the object should be completed according to planning.

End Date Parent:

Displays the planned target end of the predecessor, i.e. the parent project.

This display only appears in create and change mode and is intended as an aid, as a note is reported as soon as a project is created under a project that would lie outside the period of the parent project.

If defined in the global client settings, the system tries to adjust the time period of the parent projects automatically, if no dependencies are violated.

Maximum Effort:

This field indicates the maximum time effort. This field must not be exceeded by the effort target.

If a value has been entered here, the employees can book a maximum of as many hours on this project as you have specified.

The maximum time effort can only be specified for tasks.

Alias field for time unit:

Alias field for time unit, which should guarantee that the different fields linked to the time unit (effort_set, effort_actual, max. time effort, actual_delay, set_delay) can be handled individually.
(ZE=Unit of Time)
A day is defined as 8 hours
A month is defined as 30 days
A year is defined as 12 months

Deadline:

Specifies the deadline (latest time) by which the project must be completed.

Actual Starting Date:

Specifies the actual start date. For tasks, this field is filled with the date when a time entry was first made for this task.
For (partial) projects, this is the earliest actual start date of the tasks below it.

Estimated Delay:

Indicates the planned additional time required (unit: hrs, day, month, year). The value entered here is added to the actual delay.

Alias field for time unit:

Ensures that different fields with time units (e.g. effort target, effort actual, max. time etc.) can be handled individually.
A day is defined as 8 hours
A month is defined as 30 days
A year is defined as 12 months

Dummy:

Dummy

Actual End Date:

Indicates the actual end date. For tasks, this field is filled with the date when the task was completed.
For (partial) projects, this is the latest actual end date of the tasks below it.

Actual Effort:

The actual effort corresponds to the sum of the work actually done on tasks from time, travel or material recording. For projects/sub-projects, this value corresponds to the sum of all subordinate tasks.

Alias field for time unit:

Alias field for time unit, which should guarantee that the different fields linked to the time unit (effort_set, effort_actual, max. time effort, actual_delay, set_delay) can be handled individually.
(ZE=Unit of Time)
A day is defined as 8 hours
A month is defined as 30 days
A year is defined as 12 months

Time Elapsed:

Literal for the progression field of time, occurs in conjunction with the progression symbol, which, depending on the coloring, visualizes the progression or state of time.

The percentage of completion is calculated by dividing the actual effort and the sum of the target effort and the actual delay, multiplied by 100%.

The percentage of time spent so far is calculated by dividing the elapsed time from the start of the project to now (vZbj) by the total project duration from the target start to the target end, multiplied by 100%.

Example: effort-actual=50 ; effort-target=100; actual-delay=10; vZbj=200; total project duration=300
--> ( effort-actual / ( effort-target + actual-delay )) * 100% = degree of completion
( 50 / ( 100 + 10 )) * 100% = 45.4 % = Percentage of completion

--> ( budget-consumed / budget ) * 100% = percentage of cost expenditure
( 200 / 300 ) * 100% = 66% = Percent of time spent

----> A red bar filled to 66% is displayed because the effort expended is 10% greater than the percentage of completion.

Course of Effort:

Progress field of the effort, occurs in connection with the progress symbol, which, depending on the coloring, visualizes the progress or state of the effort. The field is calculated as follows:

The POC is calculated by dividing the actual effort by the sum of the target effort and the actual delay, multiplied by 100%.

The percentage effort to date is calculated by dividing the actual effort and the target effort, multiplied by 100%.

Example: effort-actual=50 ; effort-target=100; actual-delay=10;
--> ( Expenditure actual / ( Expenditure target + Actual delay )) * 100% = degree of completion
( 50 / ( 100 + 10 )) * 100% = 45.4 % = Percentage of completion

--> ( Expenditure-actual / Expenditure-target ) * 100% = Percentage of the expenditures made so far
( 50 / 100 ) * 100% = 50% = Percentage of expenditure to date

----> A half-filled yellow bar is displayed because the effort expended is greater than the percentage of completion. If the POC were 10% less than the effort expended, the bar would be red.




Financial block contains information on budgeting/settlement


Financial block contains budgeting information



Field Descriptions

Int. PFrm.:

This value specifies the internally planned net budget framework (target) for the persons who will execute the assigned tasks. This value is defined for projects (parent project or sub-project) and thus specifies the limit for all subordinate sub-projects or tasks. If the limit is exceeded, a warning is issued. Depending on the client setting, this frame can be increased or not by task planning.

Int.Rem.PF:

This value indicates the remaining internally planned net budget framework (target) for persons, i.e. this is the value of the int. person budget framework of the superordinate project minus all already int. planned person budget frameworks of the same project level.

Ext. PFrm.:

This value specifies the externally planned net budget framework (target) for the persons who will execute the assigned tasks. This value is defined for projects (parent or sub-project) and thus specifies the limit for all subordinate sub-projects or tasks. If the limit is exceeded, a warning is issued. Depending on the client setting, this frame can be increased or not by task planning.

Ext.Rem.PF:

This value indicates the remaining externally planned net budget framework (target) for persons, i.e. this is the value of the ext. person budget framework of the superordinate project minus all already ext. planned person budget frameworks of the same project level.

Int. MFrm.:

This value specifies the internally planned (should be) net budget framework for the material that will be required for the execution of the tasks. This value is defined for projects (parent or sub-project) and thus specifies the limit for all subordinate sub-projects or tasks. If the limit is exceeded, a warning is issued. Depending on the client setting, this limit can be increased or not by task planning.

Int.Rem.MF:

This value specifies the remaining internally planned net budget framework (target) for the material, that is, this is the value of the int. material budget framework of the superordinate project minus all the already int. planned material budget frameworks of the same project level.

Ext. MFrm.:

This value specifies the externally planned (to be) net budget framework for the material that will be required for the execution of the tasks. This value is defined for projects (parent or sub-project) and thus specifies the limit for all subordinate sub-projects or tasks. If the limit is exceeded, a warning is issued. Depending on the client setting, this limit can be increased or not by task planning.

Ext.Rem.MF:

This value specifies the remaining externally planned net budget framework (target) for the material, that is, this is the value of the ext. material budget framework of the superordinate project minus all the already ext. planned material budget frameworks of the same project level.

Type of the Budget:

Nature of the planned budget

The type of planned budget can be freely defined per client in the lookup values.

Pers. Account. Appr.:

Specifies the type of billing according to which person services are billed, for example, fixed price, person days, hours, etc.

Depending on which value is set here, this has an influence on the invoice writing.
Fixed Price: In this case, the value entered in the Intern Plan. Budget field of this project will be used as the respective fixed price amount in the invoice writing.
Per Hour Basis: Invoice items are created based on hours worked (or travel expenses recorded).
Not Invoiceable: Tasks that carry this accounting type will not be included in the invoice writing for person fixed price or person hourly basis.

Mat. Account. Appr.:

Specifies the type of settlement according to which materials are settled, for example, fixed price, hours, meters, and so on.

Depending on which value is set here, this has an influence on the invoice writing.
$message_483;: In this case, the value entered in the Intern Plan. Budget field of this project will be used as the respective fixed price amount in the invoice writing.
Per Hour Basis: Invoice line items are created based on hours, meters, or other units worked.
$message_640;: Tasks that carry this billing type will not be included in the invoice write for materials.

Int. Plan HRB:

This value indicates the internally planned net budget (target) for the persons who will carry out the assigned tasks.

Int.App.PB:

This value indicates the internally already approved net budget (target) for the persons who will carry out the assigned tasks.

Int.Act.PB:

This value indicates the net internally capitalized budget (debit) for the persons performing the assigned tasks. The capitalized budget corresponds to the approved budget for capitalized projects.

Int.Pln.PB:

This value indicates the internally planned net budget (debit) for the persons performing the assigned tasks. The planned budget is always 0.00 - because persons consume budget directly through time recording.

Int.U. HRB:

This value indicates the internally consumed net budget (actual) for the persons who have already executed assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by the time recording of the employees.

Int.Rem.PB:

This value specifies the internally still available residual net budget (target) for persons, that is, this is the difference between approved person budget - planned person budget - consumed person budget.

Int. Plan. MRB:

This value specifies the internally planned net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks.

Int.App.MB:

This value indicates the internally already approved net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks.

Int.Act.MB:

This value indicates the net internally capitalized budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks. The capitalized budget corresponds to the approved budget for capitalized projects.

Int.Pln.MB:

This value indicates the internally planned net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks. The planned budget indicates costs for orders that have not yet been delivered and therefore not yet consumed.

Int.U.MRB:

This value indicates the net (actual) budget consumed internally for materials that have already been used for assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by assigning materials to tasks or by resource planning.

Int.Rem.MB:

This value indicates the residual net budget (target) still available internally for material, i.e. this is the difference from:
Int. approved material budget - Int. planned material budget - Int. consumed material budget.

Int.Int.TB:

This value specifies the total internally planned net budget (target), that is, this is the sum of the internally planned person budget + the internally planned material budget.

Int.App.TB:

This value indicates the total internally approved net budget (target), that is, this is the sum of the internally approved person budget + the internally approved material budget.

Int.Act.TB:

This value specifies the total internally capitalized net budget (debit), that is, this is the sum of internally capitalized person budget + internally capitalized material budget.

Int.Pln.TB:

This value specifies the total internally planned net budget (target), that is, this is the sum of the internally planned person budget + the internally planned material budget.

Int.Usd.TB:

This value specifies the total internally consumed net budget (actual), that is, this is the sum of internally consumed person budget + internally consumed material budget.

Int.Rem.TB:

This value indicates the total internally available residual net budget (target), i.e. this is the sum of the internally available personnel budget + the internally available material budget.

Ext. Plan. HRB:

This value indicates the externally planned net budget (target) for the persons who will carry out the assigned tasks.

Ext.App.PB:

This value indicates the net budget (target) already approved externally for the persons who will carry out the assigned tasks.

Ext.Act.PB:

This value indicates the external capitalized net budget (debit) for the persons performing the assigned tasks. The capitalized budget corresponds to the approved budget for capitalized projects.

Ext.Pln.PB:

This value indicates the externally planned net budget (debit) for the persons performing the assigned tasks. The planned budget is always 0.00 - since persons consume budget directly through time recording.

Ext.U.HRB:

This value indicates the externally consumed net budget (actual) for the persons who have already performed assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by the time or travel expense recording of the employees.

Ext.Rem.PB:

This value specifies the externally still available residual net budget (target) for persons, that is, this is the difference between approved person budget - planned person budget - consumed person budget.

Ext. Plan. MRB:

This value specifies the externally planned net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks.

Ext.App.MB:

This value indicates the externally already approved net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks.

Ext.Act.MB:

This value indicates the externally capitalized net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks. The capitalized budget corresponds to the approved budget for capitalized projects.

Ext.Pln.MB:

This value indicates the externally planned net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks. The planned budget indicates costs for purchase orders that have not yet been delivered and therefore not yet consumed.

Ext.U. MRB:

This value indicates the externally consumed net budget (actual) for material that has already been used for assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by assigning materials/materials to tasks or by resource planning.

Ext.Rem.MB:

This value indicates the external remaining net budget (debit) available for material, i.e. this is the difference of:
Ext. approved material budget - Ext. consumed/settled material budget.

Ext.Int.TB:

This value specifies the total externally planned net budget (target), that is, this is the sum of externally planned person budget + externally planned material budget.

Ext.App.TB:

This value specifies the total externally approved net budget (target), that is, this is the sum of externally approved person budget + externally approved material budget.

Ext.Act.TB:

This value specifies the total externally capitalized net budget (target), that is, this is the sum of externally capitalized person budget + externally capitalized material budget.

Ext.Pln.TB:

This value specifies the total externally planned net budget (target), that is, this is the total of externally planned person budget + externally planned material budget.

Ext.Usd.TB:

This value specifies the total externally consumed net budget (actual), that is, this is the sum of externally consumed person budget + externally consumed material budget.

Ext.Rem.TB:

This value specifies the total externally available residual net budget (target), i.e. this is the sum of externally available personnel budget + externally available material budget.

Course of Costs:

History field of the costs, occurs in conjunction with the history symbol, which, depending on the coloring, visualizes the course or state of the costs. The calculation of the field is as follows.

The POC is calculated by dividing the actual cost by the sum of the target cost and the actual delay, multiplied by 100%.

The percentage of costs incurred to date is calculated by dividing the budget consumed by the budget, multiplied by 100%.

Example: Expenditure-actual=50 ; Expenditure-target=100; Actual-delay=10; Budget-consumed=200; Budget=300
--> ( Expenditure-actual / ( Expenditure-target + Actual-delay )) * 100% = Percentage of completion
( 50 / ( 100 + 10 )) * 100% = 45,4 % = Percentage of completion

--> ( budget-consumed / budget ) * 100% = percentage of cost expenditure
( 200 / 300 ) * 100% = 66% = Percentage of Cost Expenditure

----> A red bar filled to 66% is displayed because the effort expended is 10% greater than the percentage of completion.




Progress Block


Definition of the project progress determination
At each project level, you can define how the project progress (=completion rate) should be determined, but only for tasks, progress can be reported depending on the reporting time set.
The following methods are available:

  • Comparison of Target/Actual Effort
    The degree of completion is calculated from the sum of the actually performed actual effort for the respective tasks divided by the sum of the planned target effort plus the sum of the planned additional effort.
    This method is the most accurate, but requires a well-planned and carefully considered target effort.
    If the sum of the target efforts equals 0, i.e. no effort has been planned for any task, then the percentage of completion is always 100%.

  • Remaining effort in hours
    If an effort has already been made, then the percentage of completion is calculated by dividing the sum of the efforts made for the respective tasks by the sum of the efforts made plus the estimated remaining effort in hours.
    If remaining effort is estimated equal to 0 this means that there is no more work to be done, the task is complete and therefore the percentage of completion is equal to 100%.

  • Method 0/50/100
    The degree of completion results from the value, thereby means:
    • 0: The task has not yet been started.
    • 50: The task is being worked on.
    • 100: The task has been completed.


  • Method 0/100
    The degree of completion results from the value, thereby means:
    • 0: The task has not yet been started or the task is being worked on.
    • 100: The task has been completed.


  • Percentage remaining
    The percentage complete is obtained by subtracting 100 with the estimated percentage remaining.

  • Percentage complete
    The percentage complete is equal to the estimated percentage.



Field Descriptions

Determinat. Method:

Determination of the method how the project progress (= percentage of completion) is to be determined.

Report Date:

Determination of the reporting date when the project progress (= percentage of completion) is to be determined.

Planned-Actual-Comp.:

Calculation formula:

Target/Actual comparison= ACT (= sum of all efforts made so far)
Target (= sum of planned efforts)


The target/actual comparison is the simplest method to determine the degree of progress of a project. A prerequisite for this is good effort planning.

The percentage of completion can be adjusted at any time by changing the effort planning.
For an effective determination of the POC, all methods must be considered and evaluated together!

Cost-to-Cost Method:

Degree of prefabrication

Calculation formula:
(sum of all internal costs incurred to date) divided by (sum of all planned internal costs).

The percentage of completion is a simple method to determine the degree of progress of a project. A prerequisite for this is good cost or budget planning.

The percentage of completion can be adjusted at any time by changing the budget.
For an effective determination of the POC, all methods must be considered and evaluated together!

Rel. Perc. of Compl.:

Relative percentage of completion
For an effective determination of the percentage of completion, all methods must be considered and evaluated together!

Abs. Perc. of Compl.:

Absolute percentage of completion

The absolute POC is calculated by dividing the sum of the tasks already completed (= work packages) by the sum of all tasks.

In practice, this percentage of completion often only corresponds to the actual progress of the project if the individual planned tasks each have approximately the same duration.
For an effective determination of the degree of completion, all methods must be considered and evaluated together!

Link:

This field is optional. If a link is entered, the automatic user rights query is bypassed and the Trans_ID field is cleared.




Cost master data block


Universal mask for assigning any cost master data like cost unit, cost center, cost type etc. to different objects like master project, task, employee, material etc.



Field Descriptions

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Cost Unit:

A cost object is an object to which costs are allocated in business accounting. Usually, this is understood to be a good or service. However, other objects can also be selected as cost objects in business cost accounting, such as a process (activity-based costing), a project (project costing) or a customer (customer profitability accounting).

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Cost Center:

Cost center accounting is a component of operational cost accounting. A cost center is a spatially or organizationally delimited location of an organization where costs are incurred. Cost centers correspond, for example, to individual departments, individual machines, individual projects, individual persons or other delimited groupings.

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Cost Element:

The cost element categorizes costs incurred in cost accounting according to their own nature. Here, each cost element corresponds to an assigned task.

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Service Type:

The activity type in cost accounting is a reference value that indicates the qualitative technical description of the production activity. Here, it can be classified between productive (=value-adding) and non-productive types.




Info block


Shows general information about the currently selected project.

The last input mask of the project definition deals rather with secondary information.

Various notes can be added to a project, and the creation date of the project is also displayed.
Possible time deviations within this project are marked.

With the help of the field "RepeatType" you can specify with which frequency the project should repeat itself. Then as many projects are created as specified in the field "In advance".



Field Descriptions

Reference Num.:

A reference number may be entered in this field.

It is used for a possible reference creation to other programs.

Creation Date:

Specifies the date on which the entry was created in the database.

Repeating:

Indicates the cycle in which a project repeats (daily, weekly, etc.). If something is entered in this field, the "In advance" field must also be filled in.

In Adv.:

If you enter e.g. 5, and a monthly repetition (the field Repeating Type must be filled), then five further copies of this project are created, for each following month exactly one.

Degree of Difficulty:

Symbolizes how demanding a task is.

Annotation:

This field displays general comments about a project.

Internal Annotation:

This field is used to annotate a project for internal purposes only.


Multi Function

OK button to confirm various entries

Delete

After pressing the button Delete the selected records will be deleted. If the record is still needed, you will receive an error message.

Adapt

If the time frame of a project exceeds that of its parent(s), the "Adjust" button can be pressed, which will adjust the time frames to the new maximums.

Example: Project 2 is to be created under project 1. Project 1 starts on 3/1/2002 and ends on 4/25/2002, but project 2 should already start on 2/28/2002. To save you some steps, you can click the "Adjust" button after the system has recognized the conflict. This will set the start of project 1 to 2/28/2002, and the same will happen for any parent projects of project 1.




Resource assignments


Overview of the resources assigned to a project, subproject and/or task.



Field Descriptions

Name:

In this field the family name of the person or the name of the legal entity (e.g. company name) is displayed or entered.

Material Name:

Name or description of a material.

Material Type:

Type of a material, that is, to which material group it belongs. The material types can be defined as lookup values themselves.

Group:

This field displays the individual employee skill groups, that is, the employee areas that they cover.

Skill Name:

This field contains the names of the skills of the individual persons, e.g. "English", "Russian" or similar as skills for the group "foreign languages".

Start:

This field specifies the plan start date. When created, it is identical to the project start date when the employee was assigned, but it can be changed later.

End:

This field specifies the plan end date. When created, it is identical to the project end date on which the employee was assigned, but it can be changed later.

PP:

Monetary value, the amount of which shows the financial expenditure for the company per hour of use of a worker or a material (counterpart to VK=sales price). Here the EK (purchase price) is to be entered, which the resource receives for the current project.

Example: An employee has a purchase price of 25 €. If he works on a "normal" project, his purchase price is also 25 €. But if he works on a project that needs all his experience, the price can be adjusted to this project (e.g. price 40 €). The adjustment is also possible for the sales price.

SP:

Monetary value, the amount of which shows the financial return for the company per day of use of a worker or a material (counterpart to EK=purchase price). The sales price that the resource generates for the current project must be entered here.

Example: An employee has a sales price of 40 €. If he works on a "normal" project, his sales price is also 40 €, but if he works on a project that requires all his experience, the sales price can be adjusted to this project (e.g. sales price 60 €). The adjustment is also possible for the EK.

Effort:

Specifies how many hours an employee should spend on a task.

%:

Indicates the percentage of work performed by the employee.

Utilizat.:

Indicates the percentage to which a resource is already utilized (by other projects).

Materials always have 100% capacity utilization when allocated.

For employees, the utilization is calculated from the values of the target workday and the target effort for the task.
For example, an employee with a standard eight-hour day is assigned to a task with a target effort of 24 hours. The duration of the task is three days.
=>Within these three days, the employee can work three times eight hours according to the target workday
=>24 hours / (3 * 8 hours) => 1 => Utilization of the employee is exactly 100% for this task.
Now let's assume the same task is now to be completed in four days
=>24 hours / (4 * 8 hours) => 0.75 => Utilization of the employee is exactly 75% for this task.
If more than one employee is assigned to a task, the workload can be split so that, for example, one employee does 16 hours and the other does 8 hours.
