Monetary value, the amount of which shows the financial return for the company per day of use of a worker or a material (counterpart to EK=purchase price). The sales price that the resource generates for the current project must be entered here.

Example: An employee has a sales price of 40 €. If he works on a "normal" project, his sales price is also 40 €, but if he works on a project that requires all his experience, the sales price can be adjusted to this project (e.g. sales price 60 €). The adjustment is also possible for the EK.

Ext. Plan. MRB:

This value specifies the externally planned net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks.

Ext. App. MBud.:

This value indicates the externally already approved net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks.

Ext. Act. MBud.:

This value indicates the externally capitalized net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks. The capitalized budget corresponds to the approved budget for capitalized projects.

Ext. Plan MBud.:

This value indicates the externally planned net budget (target) for material that will be consumed for the execution of the tasks. The planned budget indicates costs for purchase orders that have not yet been delivered and therefore not yet consumed.

Ext. Used MRB:

This value indicates the externally consumed net budget (actual) for material that has already been used for assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by assigning materials/materials to tasks or by resource planning.

Ext. Inv. MRB:

This value specifies the externally settled net budget (actual) for materials. The settled budget is determined by settled materials for tasks.

Ext. Rem. MBud.:

This value indicates the external remaining net budget (debit) available for material, i.e. this is the difference of:
Ext. approved material budget - Ext. consumed/settled material budget.

Ext. Inten. TB:

This value specifies the total externally planned net budget (target), that is, this is the sum of externally planned person budget + externally planned material budget.

Ext. App. TBud.:

This value specifies the total externally approved net budget (target), that is, this is the sum of externally approved person budget + externally approved material budget.

Ext. Act. TBud.:

This value specifies the total externally capitalized net budget (target), that is, this is the sum of externally capitalized person budget + externally capitalized material budget.

Ext. Plan TBud.:

This value specifies the total externally planned net budget (target), that is, this is the total of externally planned person budget + externally planned material budget.

Ext. Used TBud.:

This value specifies the total externally consumed net budget (actual), that is, this is the sum of externally consumed person budget + externally consumed material budget.

Ext. Inv. TBud.:

This value specifies the total externally settled net budget (actual), that is, this is the total of externally settled person budget + externally settled material budget.

Ext. Rem. TBud.:

This value specifies the total externally available residual net budget (target), i.e. this is the sum of externally available personnel budget + externally available material budget.

Prs-Account.Ap.:

Specifies the type of billing according to which person services are billed, for example, fixed price, person days, hours, etc.

Depending on which value is set here, this has an influence on the invoice writing.
Fixed Price: In this case, the value entered in the Intern Plan. Budget field of this project will be used as the respective fixed price amount in the invoice writing.
Per Hour Basis: Invoice items are created based on hours worked (or travel expenses recorded).
Not Invoiceable: Tasks that carry this accounting type will not be included in the invoice writing for person fixed price or person hourly basis.

Mat-Account.Ap.:

Specifies the type of settlement according to which materials are settled, for example, fixed price, hours, meters, and so on.

Depending on which value is set here, this has an influence on the invoice writing.
$message_483;: In this case, the value entered in the Intern Plan. Budget field of this project will be used as the respective fixed price amount in the invoice writing.
Per Hour Basis: Invoice line items are created based on hours, meters, or other units worked.
$message_640;: Tasks that carry this billing type will not be included in the invoice write for materials.

Invoice Number:

The placeholder for the invoice number is an admin setting value.

FP (Invo.):

This value indicates the already externally invoiced (is) net costs for fixed price tasks. These consist of both fixed personnel and fixed material costs.

AB (Invo.):

This value indicates the already externally settled (is) net costs for hourly or quantity-based tasks. These costs consist of time recording, time material and consumable costs.

TE (Invo.):

This value indicates the already externally settled (is) net costs for trips.

MT (Invo.):

This value indicates the already externally billed (is) net cost for immediate materials.

Tot. (Invo.):

This value indicates the total net costs that have already been settled externally (is).

FP (Open):

This value indicates the externally still open, i.e. not settled (is) net costs for fixed price tasks. These are made up of both personnel and material fixed price costs.

AB (Open):

This value indicates the externally still open, i.e. not settled (is) net costs for hourly or quantity-based tasks. These costs consist of time recording, time material and consumable costs.

TE (Open):

This value indicates the externally still open, i.e. not settled (is) net costs for trips.

MT (Open):

This value indicates the externally still open, i.e. not settled (is) net costs for immediate materials.

Tot. (Open):

This value indicates externally open, i.e. not yet settled (is) total net costs.

Used Margin:

Consumption margin for a project, i.e. the difference between ext. consumed budget and int. consumed budget.

Inv.-Margin:

Invoice margin for a project, i.e. the difference between ext. settled budget and int. consumed budget.
If no invoice writing is used, this value is always negative, if int. budget was consumed.

Reporting > Projects > Detail-Report

Display of all project information in detail including change history


HTML report of all selected projects incl. cost and effort information according to adjustable filter criteria such as "project status", "time period", "project depth", "project owner" or "skills" etc.




Project selection for report


Project selection for report

Through various fields it is possible for you to limit the number of projects in a report, for example by only wanting to see all active projects, or only projects of a project manager or similar.

NOTE:
For additional information, please see the help of the respective report in the input mask.



Field Descriptions

Active:

Selecting this option displays all currently active projects.

Projects From:

By setting a date at this point, only projects that were started or planned AFTER this date will be displayed.

Project:

In Project the project or task is selected for which the key data should be displayed.

Main Project:

Top level of a project structure, under which all subprojects and tasks are subordinated.

Inactive:

Selecting this option displays all currently inactive projects.

Projects to:

By setting a date at this point, only projects whose planned or actual end date is before this date will be displayed.

Customer:

Here you can select the client of the activity (project, subproject or task).

Planned:

Selecting this option displays all currently scheduled projects.

To SubLevel:

The number you enter in this field controls how many project levels are displayed in the report.

Sublevel "0" corresponds to the highest level.

Displ. Tasks:

Here you can define whether tasks (and possibly to-dos) should also be displayed in the project selection list or not. If this checkbox is not set, only projects and subprojects are displayed.

Project Manag.:

Specifies which person should be the project manager of this project.

This field only serves as a further decision criterion in various reports, the Project Manager does not enjoy any additional rights or similar, these lie exclusively with the 1st Project Leader.

The Project Manager is only set in projects and is then also selected in the respective tasks of the project.

Green displayed persons in the selection field are project managers, which are already assigned to at least one project in this role.

Project managers are created using the role mask with role "Project Manager".

Completed:

Selecting this option displays all currently completed projects.

Max. Prj.:

Definition of the maximum number of text characters to be displayed for the project designation, i.e. if a text is too long (in particular for print formatting), the text is wrapped or truncated from the number of characters entered, depending on the "Line break" field set. If a value is entered, the project is also displayed without the project numbering.

An entry of '0' means: No text wrapping and project numbering (= default).

Project History:

If this checkbox is activated, any existing historical data records for each project are also displayed. These old data records are displayed with a blue project number and project name.

1st Project L.:

In this field the manager of a project is displayed or must be selected from a selection list. The project manager is defined once in the master project, and is then preselected as a PROPOSAL in all underlying projects.

Green displayed persons in the selection field are project leaders, which are already assigned to at least one project in this role.

Project managers are created using the role mask with role "Project Manager".

Rec. Tasks:

If this field is checked, only displayed tasks are included and costed in the higher-level projects.

If this field is unchecked, all displayable tasks are included in the parent projects and costed, even if they are not displayed.
Displayable tasks are tasks that match the global project filter criteria.

No Number:

If unchecked, the transaction numbers are not displayed.

Critical:

If this checkbox is selected, only critical projects are displayed.

Pro Rata:

If checked, the planned and target values are adjusted proportionally to the period to be displayed.

Example: For a plan budget of 1,000.00 Euro in a 2-year period, this value is displayed as 500.00 Euro if the period to be displayed is exactly half of the plan period.

Detailed:

By ticking this checkbox, the normal report is extended by additional, more detailed information.

Max. Chars:

Defines the maximum number of text characters to be displayed, i.e. if a text is too long (especially for print formatting), the text will be wrapped or truncated after the entered number of characters, depending on the "Line break" field set.

An entry of '0' means: no text wrapping. For print formatting, e.g., for the "Proof of service", the preset value of 50 (= default) is recommended.

Skill Group:

In this field, the individual employee skill groups can be selected, i.e. the employee areas they cover. The selected group ID is stored internally.

Costs:

If this field is checked, the cost fields are shown in the project report.

Effort:

If this field is checked, the effort fields are shown in the project report.

Department:

Indicates the department in which the employee works.

Text Lines:

Text line


Accept

Clicking this button saves the entered data and continues the program execution.




Project report


Project report
The project report shows all projects that meet the selection conditions on the basis of the selection conditions in the previous screen.

This report is downloadable as HTML file, see download button below.

Projects whose names are highlighted in blue indicate the historical status of the project.

This report contains the most important data of the project (possibly additional information, if Detailed Information is checked), but it can also be limited in its information content, if the fields Costs and Effort are not checked. In this case, you could also print out this report and pass it on to your customer.

Persons who do not have authorization for cost fields (e.g. normal employee or customer access) do not receive cost or expense fields in the view.



Field Descriptions

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Reporting > Projects > Net Plan Diagram

View of a project as net plan diagram with critical path


Structured graphical display of an entire project hierarchy, with each project level displayed in its own column.

Based on the project duration, the earliest start and the earliest end are calculated in forward planning, as well as the latest start and the latest end in backward planning, if a global end date has been specified.




Determine selection criteria


Define selection criteria for displaying the network.



Field Descriptions

Main Project:

Top level of a project structure, under which all subprojects and tasks are subordinated.

Pln. Start Date:

The target start date of the project is displayed or specified here, i.e. from when the project is to be started according to planning.

Critical:

If this checkbox is selected, then the critical path is also determined and displayed with red lines. The number of buffer days between two consecutive tasks serves as a basis.

Customer:

Here you can select the sold-to party of the task (project, subproject or task).

Pln. End Date:

The target end date of the respective reference object, e.g. project, time data, trip data, etc. is displayed or specified here, i.e. by when the object should be completed according to planning.

Align Workd.:

Align time dates with working days, i.e. a date must not fall on a weekend or a public holiday.

Project Manag.:

Here the project manager of the task (project, subproject or task) is selected.

Buffer Day(s):

Buffer day(s) = minimum interval in days between two consecutive tasks.

1st Project L.:

Here the project manager of the activity (project, subproject or task) is selected.


Display

By clicking on this button, the list is generated and displayed. Depending on the defined selection criteria, the list is filtered accordingly.




Display


Determination of the start and end dates of a complete project structure by means of project duration of the individual tasks (forward and backward planning).


Forward planning:
FB (Earliest Start):
= the earliest end of its predecessor plus number of given buffer days between two tasks. Possibly alignment with working days.
FE (Earliest End):
= the earliest start of this task plus number of duration in days. Possibly alignment to working days.


Backward scheduling:.
SE (Latest End):
= the latest start of its successor minus a buffer day. Possibly alignment with working days.
SB (Latest Start):
= the latest end of this task minus the duration in days. Possibly alignment to working days.


Buffer days:.
GP (total buffer):
= Day difference between latest start and earliest start.
FP (Free Buffer):
= number of days between earliest start of successor and latest end of this task.



Field Descriptions

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Reporting > Projects > Project Structure Plan (PSP)

View of a project as project structure plan


Displays the structure of a complete parent project top-down, i.e. listed from top to bottom. The project type, the project status and the evaluation characteristics can be seen at a glance by means of frames, lines and colors. If desired, the critical path is also displayed.

A variety of selection criteria such as "client", "project manager", "project manager", "project status", "time period", etc. can be defined as filter factors.




Project selection for report


Project selection for report

Through various fields it is possible for you to limit the number of projects in a report, for example by only wanting to see all active projects, or only projects of a project manager or similar.

NOTE:
For additional information, please see the help of the respective report in the input mask.



Field Descriptions

Active:

Selecting this option displays all currently active projects.

Projects From:

By setting a date at this point, only projects that were started or planned AFTER this date will be displayed.

Main Project:

Top level of a project structure, under which all subprojects and tasks are subordinated.

Project:

In Project the project or task is selected for which the key data should be displayed.

Inactive:

Selecting this option displays all currently inactive projects.

Projects to:

By setting a date at this point, only projects whose planned or actual end date is before this date will be displayed.

Customer:

Here you can select the sold-to party of the task (project, subproject or task).

Planned:

Selecting this option displays all currently scheduled projects.

Displ. Tasks:

Here you can define whether tasks (and possibly to-dos) should also be displayed in the project selection list or not. If this checkbox is not set, only projects and subprojects are displayed.

To SubLevel:

Number of buffer days between two consecutive tasks to be used as a basis for determining the critical path.

Project Manag.:

Here the project manager of the task (project, subproject or task) is selected.

Completed:

Selecting this option displays all currently completed projects.

Max. Prj.:

Definition of the maximum number of text characters to be displayed for the project designation, i.e. if a text is too long (in particular for print formatting), the text is wrapped or truncated from the number of characters entered, depending on the "Line break" field set. If a value is entered, the project is also displayed without the project numbering.

An entry of '0' means: No text wrapping and project numbering (= default).

Project History:

If this checkbox is activated, then the critical path is also determined and displayed with red lines. The number of buffer days between two consecutive tasks serves as a basis here.

1st Project L.:

Here the project manager of the activity (project, subproject or task) is selected.

Critical:

If this checkbox is selected, only critical projects are displayed.

No Number:

If unchecked, the transaction numbers are not displayed.

Rec. Tasks:

If this field is checked, only displayed tasks are included and costed in the higher-level projects.

If this field is unchecked, all displayable tasks are included in the parent projects and costed, even if they are not displayed.
Displayable tasks are tasks that match the global project filter criteria.

Max. Chars:

In this field, the maximum number of text characters to be displayed can be entered, i.e. if a text is too long, the text will be truncated from the entered number of characters.
If this field is empty, no text truncation is performed, if the value is zero, no project name is displayed.
An input of two numbers separated by comma (e.g. 120, 30) causes the text to be shortened and wrapped (here 120 characters in display, wrapping after every 30 characters).

Detailed:

By ticking this checkbox, the normal report is extended by additional, more detailed information.

Pro Rata:

If checked, the planned and target values are adjusted proportionally to the period to be displayed.

Example: For a plan budget of 1,000.00 Euro in a 2-year period, this value is displayed as 500.00 Euro if the period to be displayed is exactly half of the plan period.

Skill Group:

In this field, the individual employee skill groups can be selected, i.e. the employee areas they cover. The selected group ID is stored internally.

Costs:

If this field is checked, the cost fields are shown in the project report.

Effort:

If this field is checked, the effort fields are shown in the project report.

Department:

Indicates the department in which the employee works.

Text Lines:

Text line


Accept

Clicking this button saves the entered data and continues the program execution.




Project structure plan


Project structure plan

The work breakdown structure allows you to view and analyze the structure of a complete parent project in detail.

Using the traffic light characteristic background colors, the complete project status can be determined at first glance.
The following criteria are checked to determine the background color: project status, time period, effort and budget.


Color legend:
White background, ie.i.e. project is still in the future.
Gray background, meaning project is either inactive (dotted border) or already completed (compact border).
Green background = OK, ie. Project is on schedule, effort-wise and budget-wise.
Yellow background = hint, i.e. at least one category (time, effort or budget) is in danger of jeopardizing the project and should be checked.
Red background = Attention, ie. at least one category (time, effort, or budget) jeopardizes the project and needs to be adjusted.
Framework legend:
compact, meaning project is either active or closed (gray background).
dotted, ie. Project is either inactive (gray background) or scheduled.
Line legend:

Line from bottom left to top right, meaning the project has already been started.
Two crossed lines, meaning the project has been completed.
Red lines, meaning the project belongs to the critical path.



Field Descriptions

Text:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Reporting > Projects > MTA (Milestone-Trend-Analysis)

Graphical representation of the milestone date changes of a project during the planning process


The MTA (Milestone Trend Analysis) is a method for monitoring current project progress.

The MTA helps to better control or estimate the schedule progress of the projects. With the MTA it is possible to detect schedule shifts (delays or completions) at an early stage in order to be able to react accordingly. The prerequisite for the MTA are firmly defined milestone dates.




Control screen for selecting the display criteria


Control screen for selecting display criteria for the MTA (Milestone Trend Analysis) graph.

If a project date is changed, the new date on the change date (= report date) is defined as the new target date (= milestone date). This is entered in the MTA accordingly. If not, the old date is retained. In the course of a project, there are usually many such date shifts. Therefore, a corresponding number of new target dates (that is, the milestone date is moved back or forward) are collected for each milestone. These dates result in a trend for each milestone. This is visualized by means of the graphical evaluation of the MTA.

Based on the curve, a trend can be calculated whether, and if so, where the deadline will most likely shift.

A distinction is made between four basic principles:


  • A horizontal trend means no deadlines have been postponed (yet), i.e. the deadline will be met as planned.

  • A downward trend indicates that the planned date will be reached earlier, i.e. subsequently planned projects can be brought forward.

  • An upward trend indicates that the planned deadline cannot be met. Subsequent projects and possibly the whole project are in danger and have to be postponed.

  • A zigzag course indicates that there are uncertainties in the planning of the target dates. It cannot be estimated whether the deadline can be met or not. Possibly the whole project must be planned again.




Project Name
From the selection field, a project must be selected to the milestones exist.

Time Span from + Time Span to
The time period can be defined accordingly if desired. If no period is defined, the period is automatically determined from the display period (both target and actual period) of all milestones of the selected project.

Displ. Sub Projects
Additional display of the milestones of all sub-processes.

Table Display
Listing of all data necessary for graphical processing in a report.

Accuracy
Determining the number of report times spread over the period.

File Size
Width or height of the MTA triangle in pixels (pixels).



Field Descriptions

Selection of the activity (project, subproject, task) for which you are authoriz:

In Project, the task (project or task) for which the milestone trend analysis is to be created is selected.

Time Span from:

This field displays the point in time from which data for a project should be listed.

In input mode, a date can be entered here according to the user settings.

Displ. Sub Projects:

If the checkbox is activated, all subordinate subprojects and tasks are included in addition to the main project.

Attention!
This can lead to longer waiting times for large projects.

Accuracy:

Here you can define how many sections the actual time period should be divided into, i.e. the number of reporting points can be defined here. The higher the number the more subdivisions, the more detailed the line. For example, if a project goes over 365 days (1 year) and you enter 12 in this field, the period will be divided into 12 sections of 30-31 days each (= 365/12) and you will thus get one report time for each month. If this field remains empty or 0 is entered here, then a point is generated in the graphic for each individually determined report time of a milestone (= default setting).

Time Span to:

This field displays the date up to which the data for a project should be listed.

In input mode, a date can be entered here according to the user settings.

Table Display:

If the checkbox is activated, all data required for graphical processing will also be listed in a report, which can be displayed and downloaded as a PDF including graphics.

Size:

Here you can define how many pixels wide or high the MTA triangle should be. The value can be between 400 and 1200 pixels. The default value is 500 pixels.


Display

Graphically display all projects that match the above selection criteria.




Data report for the preparation of the graphic


Data for the preparation of the MTA in report form incl. graphics

This display corresponds to the tabular formatting of the MTA graphic. Each milestone that is displayed in the graphic is also listed here. The individual actual dates (= report dates) are numbered consecutively and displayed with the corresponding planned target dates (= milestone dates). The difference to the originally planned milestone date (= date next to milestone name) results in the shift in days, which is visually displayed in the MTA.

On the basis of the curve, the estimated end date for projects that have not yet been completed is displayed as a result, as well as the actual end date for completed projects.

End dates are always on the hypotenuse, with completed end dates shown with a border and estimated end dates in brackets. Estimated end dates can also be displayed as a line on the hypotenuse, depending on the curve progression, as the two end points are always calculated, once from the end point based on the curve progression and once as a horizontal line if the last milestone date reached is retained.



Number
Numbering of each report time point.

Actual End Date
Each report time point corresponds to the last change date of a target date.

Planned End Date
Currently set target date at the report time.

Delta-Difference
Difference in days of the current target date to the original target date.

Personnel master sheet
Graphical display of difference as a trend arrow.



Field Descriptions

No.:

Sequential numbering of each report point per milestone.

Report dates:

A report date corresponds to the actual change date of a milestone target date. If a fixed precision was entered in the selection mask, each report date corresponds to a section of the total period divided by the precision.

Milestone dates:

Target date of the milestone at the report time.

Delta-Difference:

Difference in days of the current target date (milestone date) to the original target date (milestone date). A deadline delay is represented by a positive difference, whereas an early achievement of a deadline is represented by a negative difference.

Icon:

Graphical display of the difference of the target dates as a tendency arrow. A deadline delay is symbolized as a red arrow pointing upwards, whereas an early arrival of a deadline is symbolized as a green arrow pointing downwards. Equal values are symbolized as a green diamond.

Reporting > Projects > DTA (Date-Trend-Analysis)

Graphical representation of the start and end date changes of a project during the planning process


The TTA (Schedule Trend Analysis) is a method for monitoring the current progress of a project.

The TTA helps to better control or estimate the schedule progress of the projects. With the TTA it is possible to detect schedule shifts (delays or completions) at an early stage in order to be able to react accordingly. In contrast to the MTA, no fixed milestone dates are required for this.




Control screen for selecting the display criteria


Control screen for selecting display criteria for the MTA (Milestone Trend Analysis) graph.

If a project date is changed, the new date on the change date (= report date) is defined as the new target date (= milestone date). This is entered in the MTA accordingly. If not, the old date is retained. In the course of a project, there are usually many such date shifts. Therefore, a corresponding number of new target dates (that is, the milestone date is moved back or forward) are collected for each milestone. These dates result in a trend for each milestone. This is visualized by means of the graphical evaluation of the MTA.

Based on the curve, a trend can be calculated whether, and if so, where the deadline will most likely shift.

A distinction is made between four basic principles:


  • A horizontal trend means no deadlines have been postponed (yet), i.e. the deadline will be met as planned.

  • A downward trend indicates that the planned date will be reached earlier, i.e. subsequently planned projects can be brought forward.

  • An upward trend indicates that the planned deadline cannot be met. Subsequent projects and possibly the whole project are in danger and have to be postponed.

  • A zigzag course indicates that there are uncertainties in the planning of the target dates. It cannot be estimated whether the deadline can be met or not. Possibly the whole project must be planned again.




Project Name
From the selection field, a project must be selected to the milestones exist.

Time Span from + Time Span to
The time period can be defined accordingly if desired. If no period is defined, the period is automatically determined from the display period (both target and actual period) of all milestones of the selected project.

Displ. Sub Projects
Additional display of the milestones of all sub-processes.

Table Display
Listing of all data necessary for graphical processing in a report.

Accuracy
Determining the number of report times spread over the period.

File Size
Width or height of the MTA triangle in pixels (pixels).



Field Descriptions

Selection of the activity (project, subproject, task) for which you are authoriz:

The Project field lists the tasks (projects or tasks) for which you have the appropriate rights and the corresponding filter criteria apply.

Time Span from:

This field displays the point in time from which data for a project should be listed.

In input mode, a date can be entered here according to the user settings.

Displ. Sub Projects:

If the checkbox is activated, all subordinate subprojects and tasks are included in addition to the main project.

Attention!
This can lead to longer waiting times for large projects.

Accuracy:

Sets the accuracy of the display.

Time Span to:

This field displays the date up to which the data for a project should be listed.

In input mode, a date can be entered here according to the user settings.

Table Display:

If the checkbox is activated, all data required for graphical processing will also be listed in a report, which can be displayed and downloaded as a PDF including graphics.

Size:

This field indicates the physical size of the file. With this information you can estimate, for example, how long a download would take with the usual bandwidth (-> Internet access).


Display

Graphically display all projects that match the above selection criteria.




Data report for the preparation of the graphic


Data for formatting the TTA in report form incl. graphic.
This display corresponds to the tabular formatting of the TTA graphic. Each date that is displayed in the graphic is also listed here. The individual actual dates (= report dates) are numbered consecutively and displayed with the corresponding planned target dates. The difference to the originally planned end date results in the shift in days, which is displayed visually in the TTA.
Based on the curve, the estimated end date for projects that have not yet been completed is displayed as a result, as well as the actual end date for completed projects.
End dates are always on the hypotenuse, completed end dates are shown with a border and estimated end dates are shown in brackets. Estimated end dates can also be displayed as a line on the hypotenuse, depending on the curve progression, since the two end points are always calculated, once from the end point based on the curve progression and once as a horizontal line if the last end date reached is retained.


Number
Numbering of each report time point.
Actual End Date
Each report date corresponds to the last modification date of a target date.
Planned End Date
Currently set target date at report time.
Delta-Difference
Difference in days of the current target date to the original target date.
Personnel master sheet
Graphical display of the difference as a trend arrow.



Field Descriptions

No.:

Sequential unique numbering.

Actual End Date:

The actual end date of the respective reference object, e.g. project, time data, travel data, etc. is displayed or specified here.

Project dates:

The target end date of the respective reference object, e.g. project, time data, trip data, etc. is displayed or specified here, i.e. by when the object should be completed according to planning.

Delta-Difference:

The delta hours are the difference between actual and target hours. They indicate how many hours the person has worked more or less than contractually agreed in the specified period (= overtime or minus hours).

Icon:

Specifies which icon is used with this entry.

Reporting > Projects > EVA (Earned-Value-Analysis)

The Earned Value Analysis (EVA) or Performance Value Analysis (PVA) sets the current project progress in relation to the planned value to evaluate the work performed


Earned Value Analysis (EVA) or Performance Value Analysis (LWA) relates the current project progress to the planned value in order to evaluate the work performed.




Determine selection criteria


Specify the selection and display criteria for the Earned Value Analysis (EVA).

The determined data are prepared and displayed in a graphic chart and optionally in table form.



The displayed data is determined based on the selected tasks. The underlying tasks can be influenced by the following parameters:

    .
  • Project:
    A project must be selected from the complete project list. This list contains all project types (parent project, subproject or task) to which one has corresponding rights. When selecting parent or sub-projects, the underlying tasks are automatically expanded to include all tasks subordinate to this project. When selecting a task, only that task will be used as the base.

  • Mainly responsible persons:
    If main responsible persons such as client, project manager or project manager are selected, the underlying tasks are automatically narrowed down to the tasks the selected person is assigned to.

  • Project status:
    If one or more project statuses are checked, the underlying tasks are automatically narrowed down to the tasks that have the corresponding status. If no status is checked, or if all statuses are checked, no restriction is applied.




If the determined data should be displayed not only as a graphic diagram, but also in table form, then simply the checkbox next to the Table view field must be checked. The amount of information displayed can be specified with the Display Type selection box. The choices here are:


  • Automatic
    On the basis of the number of days in the determined period, the most suitable display type is determined. "Suitable" here means: the list should consist of a maximum of 60 information lines.

  • Day(s)
    Each day of the determined time period is displayed.

  • Week(s)
    Only the first day of each week in the determined time period is displayed.

  • Month(s)
    Only the first day of each month (= first of the month) in the determined period is displayed.

  • Quarter(s)
    Only the first day of each quarter in the determined period is displayed.

  • Year(s)
    Only the first of January of each year in the determined time period is displayed.



NOTE:
The table always displays the first and last day of the determined period.
The graph chart is always based on day-exact data, i.e. the restriction of the display type has no effect on the chart, but only on the rows of the table to be displayed.



Field Descriptions

Project:

The Project field lists the tasks (projects or tasks) for which you have the appropriate rights and the corresponding filter criteria apply.

Customer (Client):

Here you can select the sold-to party of the task (project, subproject or task).

Planned:

Selecting this option displays all currently scheduled projects.

Active:

Selecting this option displays all currently active projects.

Inactive:

Selecting this option displays all currently inactive projects.

Completed:

Selecting this option displays all currently completed projects.

Project Manager:

Here the project manager of the task (project, subproject or task) is selected.

1st Project Leader:

Here the project manager of the activity (project, subproject or task) is selected.

Display Type:

Specifies how certain data should be formatted within a report.

Table Displ.:

If the checkbox is activated, all data required for graphical processing will also be listed in a report, which can be displayed and downloaded as a PDF including graphics.


Display

By clicking on this button, the list is generated and displayed. Depending on the defined selection criteria, the list is filtered accordingly.




Graphic diagram


Display graphs of Earned Value Analysis (EVA) and optional tag-specific tables.

The following data is determined and displayed:


  • Day/Date
    The abbreviation of the day of the week and the date of the determined tag-exact data.
    • .
  • Target effort - Planning effort in hours
    Planning effort is determined when a project is defined and corresponds to the summed planned effort of all subordinate tasks at a given point in time.

  • Effort. Actual - Hourly effort expended
    The hourly effort expended on a project corresponds to the summed incurred time tracking, travel, and material hours of all subordinate tasks at a given point in time.

  • S/I - Degree of Completion Target/Actual Comparison
    Indicates the percentage of a project that has been completed. The planning effort is put in relation to the hours worked.
    • .
  • PC - Planned Cost (= Planned Cost "PC")
    Planned costs are defined when a project is defined and correspond to the summed planned total internal budget (= people budget + material budget) of all subordinate tasks at a given point in time.

  • AC - Actual Cost (= Actual Cost "AC")
    The actual cost of a project corresponds to the accumulated incurred time recording, travel and material costs of all subordinate tasks at a specific point in time.

  • EV - Earned Value "EV")
    The earned value of a project corresponds to the degree of completion of all subordinate tasks at a specific point in time in relation to the planned costs and the percentage work progress determined via the target/actual comparison.

  • SV - Schedule Variance (= Schedule Variance "SV")
    The schedule variance of a project corresponds to the difference of the work value minus the planned costs of all subordinate tasks at a certain point in time.

  • CV - Cost Variance "CV")
    The cost variance of a project is equal to the difference of the activity value minus the actual costs of all subordinate tasks at a certain point in time.

  • SPI - Time Efficiency (= Schedule Performance Index "SPI")
    The time efficiency for a project indicates how large the time variance of the individual subordinate tasks is in comparison to the planned time expenditure.

  • CPI - Cost Efficiency (= Cost Performance Index "CPI")
    The cost efficiency for a project indicates how big the cost variance of the individual subordinate tasks is compared to the planned cost.



Field Descriptions

Day:

Full day of the week name.

Date:

Display of the day date for which the basic data was determined.

Plan. Eff.:

The target effort corresponds to the planned time effort in hours, man-days or man-years, etc. The estimated effort is entered when defining tasks. For projects/sub-projects, this value corresponds to the sum of all subordinate tasks.

Act. Eff.:

The actual effort corresponds to the sum of the work actually done on tasks from time, travel or material recording. For projects/sub-projects, this value corresponds to the sum of all subordinate tasks.

PAC:

Shows the percentage of a project that has already been completed. The planning effort is put in relation to the hours worked.

Any delays are taken into account in the detailed calculation.

Example:

  • without delays:
    For a task with a target effort of 100 hours, 70 hours of actual effort have already been performed => the project is 70% (=> 70 / 100) completed.
  • With delays:
    For a task with a target effort of 100 hours, 70 hours of actual effort have already been done, but there was a 5 hour delay => the project is 66% (=> 70 / 105) completed.

PC:

The planned costs (PC) are defined when a project is defined and correspond to the summed planned total internal budget (= people budget + material budget) of all subordinate tasks at a given point in time.

For the Earned Value Analysis, a linear planning progression is assumed in the specified project period, i.e. a task which, for example, goes over 10 days with a planned budget of 1,000.00 Euros is planned with a daily consumption of 100.00 Euros = 1,000.00 Euros / 10 days.
Other names for planned costs (PC):

  • Planned Value (= Planned Value "PV")
  • Target Cost of Work Scheduled "SKBA" (= Budgeted Cost of Work Scheduled "BCWS")


AC:

The Actual Costs (AC) of a project correspond to the accumulated accrued time recording, travel and material costs of all subordinate tasks at a certain point in time.
Other names for actual costs (AC):

  • Actual Value (= Actual Value "AV")
  • Actual Cost of Work Already Completed "IKAA" (= Actual Cost of Work Performed "ACWP")


EV:

The performance value (EV) of a project corresponds to the degree of completion of all subordinate tasks at a certain point in time in relation to the planned costs (PC) and the percentage work progress determined via the target/actual comparison (SI), i.e.
performance value (EV) = planned costs (PC) * target/actual comparison (SI).

The Effort Value (EV) indicates the actual value of the effort already expended at a given point in time.
Other names for performance value (EV):

  • Budgeted Cost of Work Already Completed "SKAA" (= Budgeted Cost of Work Performed "BCWP")

    • SV:

    The plan variance (SV) of a project is equal to the difference in the earned value (EV) minus the planned cost (PC) of all subordinate tasks at a given point in time, i.e.
    plan variance (SV) = earned value (EV) - planned cost (PC).

    A negative plan variance generally means, when planning is accurate, that the plan cost is higher than the value corresponding to the degree of progress already achieved, i.e. the work progress is most likely lagging behind the plan.

    A positive plan variance generally means, with exact planning, that the value corresponding to the degree of progress already achieved is higher than the plan costs, i.e. the work on the task is most likely to be completed earlier.

    CV:

    The cost variance (CV) of a project is equal to the difference of the activity value (EV) minus the actual cost (AC) of all subordinate tasks at a certain point in time, i.e.
    cost variance (CV) = activity value (EV) - actual cost (AC).

    A negative cost variance generally means, with accurate planning, that the actual cost is higher than the value corresponding to the degree of progress already achieved, i.e., the work progress is most likely lagging behind the plan.

    A positive cost variance generally means, with exact planning, that the value corresponding to the degree of progress already achieved is higher than the actual costs, i.e. the work on the task will most likely be completed earlier.

    SPI:

    The time efficiency (SPI) for a project indicates how large the time deviation of the individual subordinate tasks is from the planned time expenditure. To calculate this, the performance value (EV) is set in relation to the planned costs (PC), i.e.
    Time efficiency (SPI) = performance value (EV) / planned costs (PC).

    A time efficiency value greater than 1.00, if accurately planned, most likely indicates that tasks will be completed faster than planned, i.e., the project can be completed faster.
    For example, an SPI value of 2.00 indicates that tasks will be completed twice as fast as planned.

    A time efficiency value less than 1.00, when planned accurately, most likely indicates that the tasks will be completed slower than planned, i.e. the project is in danger of falling behind schedule or is already behind schedule.
    An SPI value of 0.50, for example, indicates that the tasks will be completed only half as fast as planned.

    CPI:

    The cost efficiency (CPI) for a project indicates how large the cost variance of the individual subordinate tasks is from the planned costs. To calculate this, the performance value (EV) is set in relation to the actual costs (AC), i.e.
    Cost efficiency (SPI) = performance value (EV) / actual costs (AC).

    A cost efficiency value greater than 1.00, if accurately planned, most likely indicates that the tasks cost less than planned, i.e., the project can be completed more cheaply.
    For example, a CPI value of 2.00 indicates that the tasks cost half as much as planned.

    A cost-effectiveness value less than 1.00, if planned accurately, most likely indicates that the tasks will cost more than planned, i.e. the project will be more expensive.
    For example, a CPI value of 0.50 indicates that the tasks will cost twice as much as planned.

Reporting > Projects > Project Personnel Deployment Plan

Graphical display of all employees in a project with planned hours for a specific timespan


This diagram shows the use in working hours of all employees within a project.

Depending on the presence of an employee and depending on the required deployment, the total number of working hours of all employees per day can vary.




Criteria selection


Criteria selection for the display in the project-staff-schedule

In the selection mask you have to select a project for which you want to see the efforts of the single employees in which time period (time period from - time period to).

If "Time from project" is ticked, the [Time span from] and [Time span to] are taken over with the corresponding values from the selected project.

Automatic", "Days", "Weeks", "Months" or "Years" can be set as the display type. If "automatic" is selected, the most suitable display type for the diagram size is set. This selection value is responsible for the division of the X-axis.

If "Add up hours" is ticked, all hours of the employee per time unit will be displayed added up, otherwise one entry per employee will be displayed next to each other.



Field Descriptions

Time Span from:

This field displays the point in time from which data for a project should be listed.

In input mode, a date can be entered here according to the user settings.

Person:

This selection field is used to select the person whose data is to be edited or displayed depending on the action.

Project:

The Project field lists the tasks (projects or tasks) for which you have the appropriate rights and the corresponding filter criteria apply.

Time Span to:

This field displays the date up to which the data for a project should be listed.

In input mode, a date can be entered here according to the user settings.

Cal. Display:

Used to specify the calendar time intervals per column, i.e. days, weeks, months or years.

If "Automatic" has been set, the calendar time interval is determined programmatically based on the length of the total period to be displayed.

Level:

The number you enter in this field controls how many project levels are displayed in the report.

Sublevel "0" corresponds to the highest level.

Time from Project:

If this checkbox is checked, the entered time span is automatically overwritten with the time data from the selected project.

Add Hours:

If this checkbox is ticked, all hours of the employee per time unit will be displayed added up, otherwise one entry per project will be displayed diagonally one behind the other.

Show Unknown:

If this checkbox is checked, "unknown" tasks will also be displayed.


Display

By clicking on this button, the list is generated and displayed. Depending on the defined selection criteria, the list is filtered accordingly.




Diagram


Diagram Explanation of the project-staff-schedule
A vertical red line is drawn in front of today's date in the diagram. Everything to the left of the line corresponds to the actual data, everything to the right of the line corresponds to the planned target data.
On the y-axis (high value) the working time (= potential) is displayed in hours (h), on the x-axis (right value) the calendar time.
For the representation approx. 10 colors are given. If more than 10 colors are needed then the colors are repeated with a slight change in brightness.

NOTE:
Attention: With many persons the color can become very fast no more distinguishable. Please limit in such a case the displayed data by means of filters, period, etc.
.



Field Descriptions

1509:

Text field

Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

Reporting > Costs > Cost Report

Extensive evaluation option for all aspects of the costs of employees in the project


Detailed listing of all costs (time recording hours and travel costs) in a freely definable period per employee and task. Optionally, time recording hours and travel expenses can be listed separately or added together.

As a filter criterion, in addition to the "person" and the "task", it is also possible to restrict using the "period" or the "client". The calendar display type is also freely adjustable between "daily", "monthly" or "annual overview".




Set display criteria for the cost report.


Set display criteria for the cost report.

Define the selection criteria according to which a cost report of the individual projects is to be prepared for the corresponding customer. In particular, the date to be displayed ("Time period from", "Time period to") can be set, as well as the underlying project.

If you have the appropriate rights, then a selection list will appear in the "Person" field, in which you can specify an employee for whom you want to see the cost report.

For client 1 the whole thing even cross-client.

SELECTION OPTIONS:
Display type
  • Automatic
    		• The program independently selects the most appropriate display format for the entered time period.
  • Day(s), Month(s), Year(s)
    		• The entered time span will be split into the selected time unit.

    Note: This will not work if "All employees" is selected, as here the employee names are the sort order.
    Project/Task
  • All projects
    		• All projects and subprojects are listed, to which the employee is assigned, and are included in the calculation.
  • Without projects
    		• Like "All projects", but all projects/tasks are not displayed, but only flow into the calculation.
  • Project (selected)
    		• Only the selected project with all subprojects will be listed, and will be included in the calculation.
    Person
  • All employees
    		• All employees of a firm, no matter if within or across clients, are listed. However, only those are displayed, which also really have entries for the selected criteria.
  • Intra-client employees
    		• Like "All employees" , but only intra-client.
  • Cross-client employees
    		• Like "All employees" , but only cross-client.
  • No employees
    		• Like "All employees" , but these are not listed individually, but their costs are added up to the corresponding projects.
  • Employee (selected)
    		• Only the cost report for the selected employee will be generated.
    Travel expenses
  • Travel expenses. Show in own line
    		• All travel expenses written down for a project will only be shown in the following line.
  • Add travel cost. Add to hourly costs
    		• All travel costs written down for a project will be added to the normal EK/VK.
  • Show travel costs alone
    		• Only the incurred travel costs for a project will be listed.
  • Do not include travel costs
    		• Only the normal costs for a project are listed, all travel costs are not calculated.


    NOTE:
    Note about travel expenses: Even if a record was marked as "not allocable" during time recording and entries were made for travel expenses at the same time, then such records are basically always included in the calculation of travel expenses.



    Field Descriptions

    Time Span from:

    This field displays the point in time from which data for a project should be listed.

    In input mode, a date can be entered here according to the user settings.

    Customer:

    Here you can select the client of the activity (project, subproject or task).

    Time Span to:

    This field displays the date up to which the data for a project should be listed.

    In input mode, a date can be entered here according to the user settings.

    Person:

    This selection field is used to select the person whose data is to be edited or displayed depending on the action.

    Display Type:

    Specifies how certain data should be formatted within a report.

    Project:

    The Project field lists the tasks (projects or tasks) for which you have the appropriate rights and the corresponding filter criteria apply.

    Show Empty Entries:

    By checking or unchecking this field, you can determine whether irrelevant entries (=blank entries) are to be displayed or not.

    If, for example, a month is listed for a project, but only two days in this month were worked for this project, you can decide here whether the entire month or only these two days should be displayed.

    Disp. Absent.:

    Determination of whether absences, i.e. days with missing time recording, should be displayed in the past or not.

    Release:

    The release indicates whether the record has been released for settlement.

    Show Unknown:

    If this checkbox is checked, "unknown" tasks will also be displayed.

    Disp. Unassign.:

    Determine whether empty assignments, that is, days without assigned plan tasks, should be displayed in the future or not.

    Clearable:

    Specifies whether or not to display offsetting entries.

    Serv.-Type:

    The activity type in cost accounting is a reference value that indicates the qualitative technical description of the production activity. Here, it can be classified between productive (=value-adding) and non-productive types.

    Disp. Estimat.:

    Determine whether or not plan estimates, that is, days with assigned plan tasks, should be displayed in the future.

    Invoiced:

    Specifies whether or not to display billed entries.

    Max. Hours/Day:

    If this field is activated, the estimated billable hours are determined from the maximum of TARGET and ACTUAL hours, i.e. in the normal case, a complete working day is used for the calculation of earnings.

    Sort by Travel:

    If this checkbox is ticked, the trips are sorted and grouped by trip type incl. trip start and end, and not by current date.

    Travel Costs:

    Here you can select how the travel expenses entered in the time recording are to be included in the listed calculation.

    Possible settings:


    Display travel expenses in separate row:
    - Travel expenses are included and displayed on the next line of the project to which they are assigned.

    Add travel expenses to employee costs:
    - Travel expenses are included and added to employee costs in the same row of the project to which they are assigned.

    Show Travel Expenses Alone:
    - Only all travel expenses incurred alone will be displayed in the listing, meaning that all other employee hourly costs will not be included in the calculation.

    Do not add travel expenses:
    - Travel costs are not included in the calculation, only employee hourly costs are listed.

    Day Specifications:

    Specify whether day specifications are displayed or not, that is, whether day specifications are to be added to the travel expenses or not.

    Payment Type:

    The payment type for travel expense receipts specifies who paid the receipt.

    There are two possibilities:

    • Company
      The receipt was paid by the company, e.g. usually for airline tickets, hotel accommodation etc.
    • Private
      The receipt was paid privately by the employee, e.g. usually for food, parking, taxi etc.


    Display

    By clicking on this button, the list is generated and displayed. Depending on the defined selection criteria, the list is filtered accordingly.




    Cost Report


    Cost Report

    Here, depending on settings in the control mask, the cost report for the selected employees is displayed.

    NOTE:
    (see control mask "Set display criteria for the cost report")



    Field Descriptions

    Day:

    Full day of the week name.

    Date:

    Used to enter or display a date of the day. If a date entry is required, the default value (today's date) is usually already preset.

    Time:

    Used to enter or display a time.

    Project:

    This field displays employees who are involved in the current project.

    Serv.-Type:

    The activity type in cost accounting is a reference value that indicates the qualitative technical description of the production activity. Here, it can be classified between productive (=value-adding) and non-productive types.

    Plan.Hrs.:

    Indicates how many hours an employee must work in a given period of time

    Act.Hrs.:

    Indicates how many hours an employee actually worked in a given time period.

    Delta:

    The delta hours are the difference between actual and target hours. They indicate how many hours the person has worked more or less than contractually agreed in the specified period (= overtime or minus hours).

    PP:

    This is the monetary value, the amount of which shows the financial expenditure for the company per hour of use of a worker or a material (counterpart to VK=sales price).

    Costs:

    Specifies whether the material always incurs costs (fixed) or only when used (variable).

    VAT:

    VAT on the total price of certain items.

    Gross:

    Invoice costs including statutory value added tax

    Inv.Hrs.:

    This field contains the billable hours for an entered activity.

    SP:

    This is the monetary value, the amount of which shows the financial return for the company per day of use of a worker or a material (counterpart to EK=purchase price).

    Income:

    Yield = Number of hours to be billed x VK

    U-Margin:

    Consumption margin for a project, i.e. the difference between ext. consumed budget and int. consumed budget.

    Rel.:

    The release indicates whether the record has been released for settlement.

    Clear:

    Specifies whether or not to display offsetting entries.

    Inv.:

    Specifies whether or not to display billed entries.

    Link:

    Jump to time recording (day)

    Reporting > Costs > Budget Report

    Evaluation (monthly, quarterly or annual reports) of the target/actual times, as well as internal and external budgets incl. invoice list


    Project reports (monthly, quarterly or annual reports)

    Display of detailed project figures regarding used budgets in a specified period of time.




    Selection criteria


    Define criteria for limiting the project report (project, client, display type, time period, etc.)



    Field Descriptions

    Project:

    The Project field lists the tasks (projects or tasks) for which you have the appropriate rights and the corresponding filter criteria apply.

    Customer:

    Here you can select the sold-to party of the task (project, subproject or task).

    Display Type:

    Selection field for selecting in which time display type the report is to be displayed. Monthly, quarterly or yearly.

    Prj.-Category:

    Define filter categories for projects or select them in a selection field.

    Time Span from:

    This field displays the point in time from which data for a project should be listed.

    In input mode, a date can be entered here according to the user settings.

    Text:

    Text field

    Variable text field that can be customized programmatically.

    Time Span to:

    This field displays the date up to which the data for a project should be listed.

    In input mode, a date can be entered here according to the user settings.

    Time auto.:

    If this checkbox is ticked, the necessary period is determined automatically.

    Adjust Rounding Val.:

    If this checkbox is selected, an attempt is made to adjust rounded values.

    Example:
    A time entry of 0,25 hrs with an hourly rate of 86,50 €/hour = 21,625 € budget consumption, i.e. rounded 21,63 €. However, a back calculation from the budget consumption to the hourly rate results in 21.63 € / 0.25 hr = 86.52 €/hour.

    With activated "Adjust rounding values" this hourly rate is compared with assigned hourly rates and corrected to the closest one.

    Actual Effort:

    The actual effort corresponds to the sum of the work actually done on tasks from time, travel or material recording. For projects/sub-projects, this value corresponds to the sum of all subordinate tasks.

    Int. Used Total Bud.:

    This value specifies the total internally consumed net budget (actual), that is, this is the sum of internally consumed person budget + internally consumed material budget.

    Ext. Used Total Bud:

    This value specifies the total externally consumed net budget (actual), that is, this is the sum of externally consumed person budget + externally consumed material budget.

    Cat.:

    In this field, the category is selected via a selection field.

    Inv.-Margin:

    Invoice margin for a project, i.e. the difference between ext. settled budget and int. consumed budget.
    If no invoice writing is used, this value is always negative, if int. budget was consumed.

    Inv. Position:

    This field contains the unique identification number of the corresponding item in the invoice.

    If this checkbox is ticked, all matching invoice positions will be listed in the report.


    Display

    By clicking on this button, the list is generated and displayed. Depending on the defined selection criteria, the list is filtered accordingly.




    Project data


    Detailed listing of project data, depending on previously selected criteria.



    Field Descriptions

    Time Period:

    Displays the runtime of the project in a combined field.

    Actual Effort:

    The actual effort corresponds to the sum of the work actually done on tasks from time, travel or material recording. For projects/sub-projects, this value corresponds to the sum of all subordinate tasks.

    HourlyCost:

    This is the monetary value, the amount of which shows the financial expenditure for the company per hour of use of a worker or a material (counterpart to VK=sales price).

    Int. Used HRB:

    This value indicates the internally consumed net budget (actual) for the persons who have already executed assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by the time recording of the employees.

    Int. Used PII:

    This value indicates the net (actual) budget consumed internally for the person input invoices paid for tasks already assigned. The consumed budget is determined by the entered incoming invoices.

    Int. Used TCst.:

    This value specifies the internally consumed net budget (actual) for trips that were posted to assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by the travel expense entry of the employees.

    Int. Used MRB:

    This value indicates the net (actual) budget consumed internally for materials that have already been used for assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by assigning materials to tasks or by resource planning.

    Int. Used MII:

    This value indicates the net (actual) budget consumed internally for the material purchase invoices paid for tasks already assigned. The consumed budget is determined by the incoming invoices entered.

    Int. Budget:

    This is a general internal budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Int. Budget:

    This is a general internal budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Int. Budget:

    This is a general internal budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Int. Budget:

    This is a general internal budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Int. Budget:

    This is a general internal budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Int. Budget:

    This is a general internal budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Int. Budget:

    This is a general internal budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Int. Budget:

    This is a general internal budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Int. Budget:

    This is a general internal budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Int. Budget:

    This is a general internal budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Int. Sum:

    This value specifies the total of the internally consumed net budget (actual) for personnel, travel, and material costs.

    Int. Cumm. Sum.:

    This value specifies the cumulative total of the internally consumed net budget (actual) for personnel, travel, and material costs for a year.

    Hrly-Yield:

    This is the monetary value, the amount of which shows the financial return for the company per day of use of a worker or a material (counterpart to EK=purchase price).

    Ext. Used HRB:

    This value indicates the externally consumed net budget (actual) for the persons who have already performed assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by the time or travel expense recording of the employees.

    Ext. Used TCst.:

    This value specifies the externally consumed net budget (actual) for trips that were posted to assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by the travel expense entry of the employees.

    Ext. Used MRB:

    This value indicates the externally consumed net budget (actual) for material that has already been used for assigned tasks. The consumed budget is determined by assigning materials/materials to tasks or by resource planning.

    Ext. Budget:

    This is a general external budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Ext. Budget:

    This is a general external budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Ext. Budget:

    This is a general external budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Ext. Budget:

    This is a general external budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Ext. Budget:

    This is a general external budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Ext. Budget:

    This is a general external budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Ext. Budget:

    This is a general external budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Ext. Budget:

    This is a general external budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Ext. Budget:

    This is a general external budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Ext. Budget:

    This is a general external budget field which can be adjusted in the report etc. depending on the usage.

    Ext. Sum:

    This value specifies the total of the externally consumed net budget (actual) for personnel, travel, and material costs.

    Ext. Cumm. Sum.:

    This value specifies the cumulative total of the externally consumed net budget (actual) for personnel, travel, and material costs for a year.

    Inv.-Margin:

    Invoice margin for a project, i.e. the difference between ext. settled budget and int. consumed budget.
    If no invoice writing is used, this value is always negative, if int. budget was consumed.

    cumm. Margin:

    This field shows the cumulative margin for the project for one year.

    Reporting > Costs > Project Codes

    Important codes of a project on any level, i.e. hours, costs, degree of completion, turnover, as well as the already billed costs


    This report shows the most important data of a project on any level, i.e. the hours, the costs, the degree of completion, the turnover and the already billed costs.




    Select project


    Select the project for which the project codes are to be created.



    Field Descriptions

    Project:

    The Project field lists the tasks (projects or tasks) for which you have the appropriate rights and the corresponding filter criteria apply.


    Display

    By clicking on this button, the list is generated and displayed. Depending on the defined selection criteria, the list is filtered accordingly.




    Project key figures Report


    Listing of all necessary parameters for the determination of the project key figures.



    Field Descriptions

    Employee:

    Shows which employees are assigned to a project as workers.

    In the case of (sub-)projects, all employees who are assigned to the respective subtasks are displayed here.

    Targ. Hrs.:

    Number of cumulative target hours

    Act. Hrs.:

    Number of cumulative actual hours worked

    Prod. Hrs.:

    Number of cumulative actual productive hours worked

    H-Wage (I):

    Internal hourly rate

    H-Wage (E):

    External hourly rate

    Prod. (I):

    Value of internal productive hours

    Prod. (E):

    Value of external productive hours

    D.Rate (I):

    Internal power price

    D.Rate (E):

    External power price

    Fix.P. (I):

    Fixed price internal

    Fix.P.(E):

    Fixed price External

    Fin.:

    The degree of processing indicates:

    • in internal fixed-price projects (=internal plant contracts)
      the ratio of the value of the services rendered (=productive working time multiplied by the EK price of the employee per time unit) to the internal fixed-price budget (=total output of the plant).
    • for external fixed price projects (=external plant contracts)
      the ratio of the value of the services rendered (=productive working time multiplied by the sales price of the employee per time unit) to the external fixed price budget (=total output of the plant).
    • in internal projects on an hourly basis (=service contracts internal)
      the ratio of the value of the service rendered (=productive working time multiplied by the EK price of the employee per time unit) to the estimated total output (=estimated target effort multiplied by the EK price of the employee per time unit at.
    • for external projects on an hourly basis (=external service contracts)
      the ratio of the value of the service rendered (=productive working time multiplied by the sales price of the employee per time unit) to the estimated total service (=estimated target effort multiplied by the sales price of the employee per time unit)

    .

    PoC:

    The percentage of completion indicates the ratio of the actual ACTUAL expense to the estimated TARGET expense.

    If the actual effort is greater than the target effort or if a project has already been completed, the percentage of completion is always 100%.

    Sales (T):

    Total revenue is calculated by multiplying the total price by the percentage of completion.

    Sales (P):

    Revenue to the previous month is calculated by multiplying the total price to the previous month by the percentage of completion for the previous month.

    Sales (M):

    The turnover in the current month is calculated from the difference between the total turnover and the turnover up to the previous month.

    Invoice(P):

    Total of all services already billed up to the previous month.

    Reporting > Progress > Project Plan Statuses

    Listing and evaluation of the selected projects on the basis of the schedule deviation and the degree of completion based on target/actual comparison


    Listing and evaluation of the selected projects on the basis of the schedule variance as well as the degree of completion based on the target/actual comparison.

    If selected, the report can also display history information up to 12 months in the past or the selected figures in a graphical chart.




    Select project


    Select the start operation for which the performance evaluation is to be created.



    Field Descriptions

    Project:

    The Project field lists the tasks (projects or tasks) for which you have the appropriate rights and the corresponding filter criteria apply.

    History:

    If this checkbox is activated, any existing historical data records for each project are also displayed. These old data records are displayed with a blue project number and project name.

    Detailed:

    By ticking this checkbox, the normal report is extended by additional, more detailed information.

    Picture:

    Assigned image in PNG, JPG, GIF or BMP format.


    Display

    By clicking on this button, the list is generated and displayed. Depending on the defined selection criteria, the list is filtered accordingly.




    Project list


    Listing of key figures per project incl. evaluation of past performance.



    Field Descriptions

    Project:

    This field displays employees who are involved in the current project.

    Stat.:

    This field shows how far a project has already progressed. In input mode, you can assign an attribute from a selection list to a project here, which reflects whether or how far a project is already advanced.

    The status can also be used to decide whether project data should be included in a report or not.

    Start:

    The target start date of the project is displayed or specified here, i.e. from when the project is to be started according to planning.

    End:

    The target end date of the respective reference object, e.g. project, time data, trip data, etc. is displayed or specified here, i.e. by when the object should be completed according to planning.

    Days:

    Display of the days after the target start date

    Plan.:

    Display of target hours

    Text:

    Display of the unit: h = hours

    Act.:

    Display of actual hours

    Prod.:

    Display of productive hours (e.g. production, support, etc.)

    I-Hrs:

    Display of billable hours

    PAC:

    Shows the percentage of a project that has already been completed. The planning effort is put in relation to the hours worked.

    Any delays are taken into account in the detailed calculation.

    Example:

    • without delays:
      For a task with a target effort of 100 hours, 70 hours of actual effort have already been performed => the project is 70% (=> 70 / 100) completed.
    • With delays:
      For a task with a target effort of 100 hours, 70 hours of actual effort have already been done, but there was a 5 hour delay => the project is 66% (=> 70 / 105) completed.


    Project

    Clicking this button will make the changes.




    Report on performance evaluation


    Report on the progress of the percentage of completion, including a list of the necessary parameters, also in history.



    Field Descriptions

    Project:

    This field displays employees who are involved in the current project.

    Stat.:

    This field shows how far a project has already progressed. In input mode, you can assign an attribute from a selection list to a project here, which reflects whether or how far a project is already advanced.

    The status can also be used to decide whether project data should be included in a report or not.

    Start:

    The target start date of the project is displayed or specified here, i.e. from when the project is to be started according to planning.

    End:

    The target end date of the respective reference object, e.g. project, time data, trip data, etc. is displayed or specified here, i.e. by when the object should be completed according to planning.

    Days:

    Display of the days after the target start date

    Plan.:

    Indicates how many hours an employee must work in a given period of time

    Act.:

    Indicates how many hours an employee actually worked in a given time period.

    Prod.:

    Determines whether an activity type is productive (= value-added) or not.

    I-Hrs:

    This field contains the billable hours for an entered activity.

    PAC:

    Shows the percentage of a project that has already been completed. The planning effort is put in relation to the hours worked.

    Any delays are taken into account in the detailed calculation.

    Example:

    • without delays:
      For a task with a target effort of 100 hours, 70 hours of actual effort have already been performed => the project is 70% (=> 70 / 100) completed.
    • With delays:
      For a task with a target effort of 100 hours, 70 hours of actual effort have already been done, but there was a 5 hour delay => the project is 66% (=> 70 / 105) completed.

    Reporting > Progress > Project Progress Request
